pets.name: A Dozen Roses
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: A Dozen Roses is the sweetest bouquet you'll ever cuddle! 🌹 This lovely lady is playful and energetic, full of personality, loving, curious, and always looking to brighten your day with tail wags and warm snuggles. We've never heard her bark! She's as quiet as she is charming, making her the perfect companion for cozy homes and calm vibes. Meet A Dozen Roses! 🌹 This sweet three-year-old pup is as charming as her name! Found as a stray, A Dozen Roses has quickly won over the hearts of the shelter staff with her affectionate nature and love for snuggles. She's highly social, enjoys pets, and is eager to learn. She has no known reactivity to other dogs on leash, but since her history is a mystery, slow introductions to other pets are recommended. She's an energetic girl who thrives on daily exercise, training, and enrichment activities like food puzzles and hide-and-seek games. A Dozen Roses is still working on her manners-she sometimes jumps on people and counter-surfs-but with patience and positive reinforcement training, she'll blossom into the perfect companion. 🐾 Personality: Affectionate, playful, eager to learn 🏡 Ideal Home: A patient adopter who can provide training, structure, and daily activity

Check out this adorable video of me on TikTok! Click here to experience the cuteness!

My BB wrote: Adopt "A Dozen Roses" (ID:220179) Today we took out "A Dozen Doses" who we decided to call "Rosie." This girly is everything you could possibly want in a companion pet. She is quick to love whoever she is with, gentle to take treats with a soft mouth and already knows "sit"! From the moment we met her she greeted us by jumping and giving us a near hug- soooooo friendly! She was enthusiastic to walk and was wiggling all over the sidewalk. She loves toys and can be so silly. She doesn't mind if you take her toy, either. Though she wants to eat every morsel of food we come across, she was not hard to walk and her tail was wagging the entire time. She showed no reactivity to dogs on leash, either. There is nothing that could shake her happiness!! What makes her unique is she was equally as happy to sit next to us while we ate lunch without any complaints. She sat beside us patiently waiting for us to be finished. She gave little tippy taps before we gave her a treat because she was so excited! Her little snorts while she sniffs sound just like a little piggy and it is so endearing. When we stopped at a coffee shop, she even took a little nap after our long walk! She would be such a good companion for a family ready to open their heart to a sweet, happy and cuddly girl. She would be excited to go on a long walk with you but also down to chill out for a movie night and cuddle up next to you. She could be great for a studio apartment or a big house with a yard. Adopt " A Dozen Roaka Rosie, she is ready to come home with you today!!!!!!

pets.name: Alder
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I lived with children in my previous home.

I am playful and cute!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

pets.name: Almond
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Almond!

Almond is a 3-year-old large mixed breed who was found as a stray in the Bronx and has since spent time in a foster home. This affectionate and playful girl is eager to find her forever home where she can be loved and cherished.

My Ideal Home
Almond would thrive in a home that provides both structure and activity. She has an energetic personality and would benefit from regular exercise, training, and positive reinforcement. She is best suited for an adult-only home or a home with older children who can respect her space and help reinforce good manners.

Good with Kids?
Almond would do best in a home without young children due to her excitable nature and tendency to jump up in a social manner. Older kids who understand dog behavior may be a better fit.

Good with Other Dogs?
Almond has had mixed reactions to other dogs-sometimes greeting them with a loose, wiggly body and other times barking and jumping at the fence. She would need slow, positive introductions if placed in a home with another dog.

Good with Cats?
Unknown-she has not been tested with cats.

Leash Manners
Almond is strong on the leash and can be reactive toward dogs and small animals while walking. A front-clip harness and reward-based training will help manage this behavior.

Overall Health
She has no ongoing medical concerns, though she is slightly overweight and would benefit from a balanced diet and exercise.

Behavior Determination
Level 3 (Experienced Adopters Recommended) - Almond is a sweet and affectionate dog who loves attention but needs continued training for her manners, anxiety, and leash reactivity. She thrives with positive reinforcement and would do best in a structured environment.

Fun Fact
Almond has a reputation for being a "kissing machine"! If you're not careful, you'll get an unexpected smooch attack from this affectionate girl.

What Her Friends Say
💬 "Almond is very sweet! She loves to play, licks a lot as a show of love, and enjoys belly rubs. She listens to commands like sit, wait, and go." -Her Foster
💬 "She was the perfect Borough Break buddy-affectionate, playful, and well-behaved on leash. She made our day and will make someone very happy!" -Volunteer

If you're looking for a fun-loving, affectionate dog who will bring energy and joy into your life, Almond could be the perfect match for you! Come meet her today! 🐾

A staff member writes: Almond may be a little nutty (in the best way!), but her affection and loyalty are truly unmatched. Whether you're out for a stroll or just relaxing at home, Almond is always by your side, ready to share her love and bring joy to your life. If you're looking for a furry friend who's as sweet as her name and will make your world a little brighter, Almond is your girl!

pets.name: Amy
pets.summaryHtml:
My Foster Writes: 
Amy is a loving, loyal foster dog with a personality as big as her heart. Just like humans are a work in progress, so is she and she is progressing kin leaps and bounds. Her quirks make her unique, her energy is contagious, and her affectionate nature leaves a lasting impression on everyone she meets. Whether she's winning hearts in the neighborhood or mastering new directions or tricks, Amy is a dog who will bring endless joy and laughter to her forever home.
VELCRO LOVE
"Amy's got love that's hard to miss,
A playful spirit wrapped in bliss.
With a heart so big, she's pure delight,
Ready to make your world shine bright!"

pets.name: Apollo
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Apollo
pets.summaryHtml:
MEET APOLLO! Apollo was lovingly surrendered to ACC when his former person faced major life changes and could no longer keep him. He arrived wiggly, social, and ready to make new friends.

MY IDEAL HOME An experienced, adult-only home that enjoys an active, affectionate dog and can provide structure, training, and daily exercise. Apollo thrives with routine, enrichment (puzzle feeders, sniffy walks, fetch), and positive reinforcement to channel his enthusiasm and big feelings.

GOOD WITH KIDS? Recommended adult-only (no children under 13) due to noted excitement, jumpy greetings, and impulse-control/touch-sensitivity in handling.

GOOD WITH OTHER PETS? History suggests he can be shy with dogs and prefers contact on his own terms. In a shelter meet, he appeared conflicted and disengaged after brief greetings. Slow, structured introductions to a well-matched, respectful dog only. Cats: unknown.

LEASH MANNERS Energetic walker who may pull and alert-bark when aroused. A front-clip harness, distance management, and reward-based training will help build loose-leash skills. He's a very excited greeter and is learning "four on the floor," gentler treat-taking, and calm handling.

OVERALL HEALTH Apollo is a young adult in good health and will be neutered prior to adoption. Recent kennel cough and tummy upset resolved with supportive care, and he's back to his cheerful self.

BEHAVIOR DETERMINATION Level 3 - High-energy, affectionate dog with basic-manners and impulse-control needs (jumpy/mouthy), touch sensitivity for some handling, and strong leash pulling. He'll succeed with decompression, consistent routines, trade-up games, and force-free training.

OTHER FUN FACTS "A happy meatball" who leans in for pets and wiggles for attention. Crate trained (up to ~5 hours), loves car rides, and knows sit/down/paw. Fetch fan, snack detective, and champion cuddler once settled - Apollo is ready to be someone's joyful sidekick.

pets.name: Apple Jacks
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Apple Jacks arrived at the care center as a stray. In the care center he becomes tense during interactions and avoids engagement when he is uncomfortable or pressured, flinching and disengaging. During his medical exam, he was growling, lunging, snapping when attempting exam of his head, and remains fearful in the care center. As a result, we recommend she is placed with one of our New Hope Partners.

pets.name: Archibald
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

pets.name: Arrow
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Ash
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Ash is at risk due to behavioral concerns. Ash arrived at the Care Center as an owner surrender due to housing concerns. Upon intake Ash was noted to be social with staff, allow handling, but also attempted to mount. Despite efforts to keep him comfortable at the Care Center, Ash has been showing signs of deterioration and low threshold for arousal. Ash has been reported to be banging on his transfer door and digging/scratching around the drain cover in his kennel during active and inactive room times. Additionally, Ash be noted to attempt to mount handlers during walks. Ash is treat motivated and exuberantly social with familiar staff. Medically, Ash is apparently healthy.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have potential behavior challenges that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'll need daily interaction with you as I get used to my new life.

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

pets.name: Auburr
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Auburr is at risk due to behavioral reasons. Initially Auburr was observed to be highly fearful. Noted to be have a tucked tail and attempt to flee (scaling the walls) when handlers approach. Recently Auburr has warmed up to handlers, however she is noted to have a low threshold for arousal. Noted to jump up and bite the leash when handlers attempt to re-leash her and mouth handlers arms with hard pressure. She has also been observed to jump up on handlers and jump at handlers while on leash. During one instance Auburr was observed to bare teeth towards a handler while she was in a pop up crate. Medically Auburr has undetermined allergies, alopecia, an umbilical hernia, and pyoderma. Auburr arrived at MACC as a stray with no known history. During her stay in the care center Auburr has been observed to be highly fearful. Noted to have a tense body tucked tail and hypervigilant while on leash. In kennel Auburr is noted to attempt to flee (scaling the walls) when handlers approach. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home.

pets.name: Aurora
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Meet Aurora, a beautiful and affectionate grey land seal who is as smart as she is loving. She's food motivated, quick to learn, and lights up when it's time for training. Aurora thrives on enrichment and loves anything that keeps her mind busy, from puzzle feeders and lick mats to her favorite food toys. At home, she's a mix of curiosity and sweetness. She sleeps through the night in her crate, loves belly rubs, and has the most endearing habit of nursing on soft things like her bed or toys when she's settling down. She's fully house trained now and even lets you know when she needs to go outside. Aurora is still learning how to stay calm during exciting moments, especially around other dogs, and she's been working closely with a trainer. She does best with a steady routine, gentle guidance, and someone who enjoys helping her learn. She would thrive with an experienced adopter who can offer structure, exercise, and plenty of love. In return, Aurora will bring warmth, goofiness, and endless affection to your home.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

pets.name: Aurora
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Aurora is on the at-risk list due to behavior concerns. Aurora has shown kennel reactivity in the care center, including repeated kennel fighting and lunging at adjacent dogs during entering and exiting kennel rooms. While she can be social and affectionate with staff in calmer environments, leaning into petting and exploring the room, her reactivity toward nearby dogs remains significant and is difficult to handle safely at times. Aurora does have a bite history from her previous home towards a raccoon and has bitten a dog during playgroup. The bite to the other dog did not break skin or draw blood. Medically, Aurora is overweight.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Avra
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Avra!

Avra came to ACC via the 114th Precinct after he was found in Astoria Park. His microchip traced to a previous owner, but no one responded, so he's now looking for a fresh start with a family of his own.

My Ideal Home
A patient, structured home that enjoys training and enrichment. Avra is a young, bouncy guy who thrives with routine, clear cues, and positive reinforcement. Think sniffy walks, puzzle feeders, and calm decompression time.

Good with Kids?
Recommended no very young children (under 5) due to jumpy greetings, leash-biting when excited, and general big-dog enthusiasm. Dog-savvy older kids could be a match with guidance.

Good with Other Pets?
Dog history is limited. In shelter meets he was loose/wiggly at first but became very exuberant, ignoring corrections. We recommend slow, structured introductions to a well-matched, tolerant dog, and no dog parks while he builds skills.
Cats: unknown.

Leash Manners
Mild puller who loves to say hi. He can get overstimulated and play-grab the leash or jump when excited. He responds to redirection with toys/food and does best with a front-clip harness, "four on the floor," and reward-based training (pattern games, engage/disengage).

Overall Health
Avra arrived with allergic dermatitis/alopecia that's improving on treatment (Apoquel course completed, cefpodoxime, medicated mousse). He's heartworm negative and up to date on core vaccines. He is currently not neutered; there's a temporary spay/neuter waiver while his skin finishes healing, and he can be neutered once medically cleared.

Behavior Determination
Level 2 (no young kids) - Social, wiggly, and affectionate; needs polishing on impulse control and cooperative handling while his skin is sensitive. He'll shine with consistency, decompression, and force-free training.

Other Fun Facts
Treat-motivated, offers play bows, and loves attention.
He tolerated fitting a harness/shirt for skin protection and happily munched cheese during his session.
Big heart, bigger wiggles - Avra can't wait to be someone's goofy, loyal sidekick. A volunteer writes: I am not prepared for the wonder that is Avra when I go to fetch him for his walk. 80lbs, in a pastel hoodie, sitting on his bed looking at me. He approaches quietly with his ears back and wiggles through his body. I learned that when he arrived he was tentative about going on walks, but that is certainly no longer the case! He knows the routine and is excited to get a break from his kennel, and uses his full 80lbs to lead me outside. He doesn't yet know that he'll get time in the yard, and his happiness when we get there

pets.name: Bababooey
pets.summaryHtml:
My Boroughbreaker writes: I heard that Bababooey was fearful when he first arrived at the shelter, but he shows no sign of that now! He was SO excited to head out for the day, and thrilled to interact with anyone who came his way. He's very interested in other dogs, and wants to meet them all. He still has a lot of puppy energy (I suspect he'd be a great running companion) and could probably benefit from a little leash training, but he's so smart and I'm sure he'd learn quickly. He already sits on command and lies down when directed. He also loves food, but it VERY gentle when taking a treat from your hand. Also, if you sit down, he immediately comes up and puts his front paws and head in your lap, and will stay for the longest time if you give him skritches. He's a total sweetheart.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am finding the shelter a little overwhelming, but when it's just you and me and some peace and quiet you'll see what a love bug I am.

I can be slow to adjust to new environments. I prefer to take things at my own pace.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

pets.name: Baklava
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Baklava arrived to MACC as a stray with no known history. Initially when he arrived Baklava was obsvered to have handling sensitivity and a low threshold for arousal. Recently Baklava has been obsvered to be highly rope reactive. Noted to jump up and bite the leash intelsy. This behavior is not able to be redirected easily and will even tip into alligator rolling. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

A Volunteer Wrote: This boy is an angel! He's in a pop-up crate in a busy hallway-- a very stressful situation for any sentient being-but when he has the opportunity to leave it all behind on a walk, he is so gentle, so affectionate, and so grateful. Volunteers shout him with all kinds of praise, but what comes up the most often is how eager he is to be loved, and how incredibly endearing he is. Please, won't you get him out of his pop up crate forever and shower him with all the love he deserves? He-and we, the many who love him-would be so grateful!

Initially when he arrived Baklava was obsvered to have handling sensitivity and a low threshold for arousal. Recently Baklava has been obsvered to be highly rope reactive. Noted to jump up and bite the leash intelsy. This behavior is not able to be redirected easily and will even tip into alligator rolling. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home. What my friends at ACC say about me: My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet! It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children. I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them. I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you. A Volunteer Wrote: This boy is an angel! He's in a pop-up crate in a busy hallway-- a very stressful situation for any sentient being-but when he has the opportunity to leave it all behind on a walk, he is so gentle, so affectionate, and so grateful. Volunteers shout him with all kinds of praise, but what comes up the most often is how eager he is to be loved, and how incredibly endearing he is. Please, won't you get him out of his pop up crate forever and shower him with all the love he deserves? He-and we, the many who love him-would be so grateful!

pets.name: Bark Vader
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Bark Vader arrived at MACC as a stray with no known history. During his stay in the care center Bark has been obsvered to be highly dog reactive and have handling sensitivity. Bark will charge towards other dogs while in the yard and in the kennel room he will pull hard towards them with a tense body. During one instance after reactive to another dog in the kennel room, Bark turned towards the handler and began jumping towards them. he then escalated to thrashing and flailing while on leash. Bark was also obsvered to head whip towards handlers when they adjust the leash and when they go to clip their leash. Due to the detailed behavior we recommend an experienced adult only, single pet home that make no trips to the dog park.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

pets.name: Bartholomew
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

pets.name: Beauregarde
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Bella
pets.summaryHtml:
Another foster writes: Do you love snuggling, the sound of a gentle snore, and perhaps adorable underbites? Then Bella is your gal. This incredibly happy, adaptable dog always has a smile on her face and is ready with a "woo woo" of excitement for her favorite things - meals, walks, or someone coming home to snuggle her. Don't let the powdered sugar face fool you, this slightly senior girl has some LIFE to live and lots of adorably sassy opinions on how she'd like to live it (with a pillow, and under a blanket, if you please! and plenty of time to sniff on walks). She'll walk for miles on a loose leash, sniffing as she goes. She is THRILLED when a stranger calls her over for pets, throwing herself at them butt-first and nudging their hand if they stop petting too soon. She struggles with seeing other dogs, but is easily redirected if you keep an eye out for potential triggers and redirect her before she's seen them. Beyond that she is a snuggly, sassy, silly, sleeeeepy wonder dog who would love nothing more than to cuddle up and show you her perfect personality and equally perfect teefers sticking out from that underbite. My Foster Writes: BELLA is the HAPPIEST and SWEETEST dog I have ever met. She is a manatee, snuggler and also a mermaid. If you seek a low energy and easy baby that sleeps all day and only maintenance required is love, this is your girl. I'm not sure I believe that Bella is 9YO -- she looks younger and seems too healthy, no joint or other problems. Her coat is super glossy and sleek. It breaks my heart that someone dropped her off at ACC after 9 years, and this granny deserves the happiest of her golden years. I cannot recommend her highly enough. She is a true gem. And I have worked with over hundreds of dogs in the past year, training. Bella is one of a kind. (I have never seen her break into a run, so her speeds might be sleep, rest and some walking. AND she does snore just above a whisper while I work from home -- it's very relaxing. Bella can be reactive with others dogs. She is easily redirected, has improved with me and I am confident will become less so over time.)

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I am a sweet, social, older gal, looking for the perfect forever home!

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

There is an adorable video of me on Instagram! Click here to experience the cuteness!

pets.name: Bellarina
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Bellarina is on the at risk list for medical concerns. Bellarina came in through an owner surrender as her owners were unable to afford vet care. On arrival at the shelter, Bellarina was diagnosed with diabetes. She has started insulin injections and is eating her diabetic diet with a very good appetite. Bellarina needs more care than we can provide at the shelter.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

pets.name: Bellini
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am looking for a home with a patient person.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

My boroughbreaker writes: Bellini is a sweetheart. She is very curious to smell everything and happy to see people. She can be patient wherever you go but does plop down if she's tired. She didn't bark with me at all. She listens if I say drop it or stop. She doesn't know sit yet. She got so many compliments from many people I wish I had an adopt me leash or vest for her. However, her Halloween costume was great. She did get little scared of loud noises and big cars but some pets and reassurance she's okay. She loved walking around Central Park. She didn't like the treats the cafe gave so maybe she likes particular treats. If I could adopt her, I would. Bellini arrived at MACC as a stray with no known history. During her stay in the care center she has been observed to be highly fearful and has allowed limited handling. Noted to baulk, pancake, and refuse to walk while on leash. Bellini is also noted to escalate to thrashing when feeling leash pressure. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home. Bellini is a super sweet pup. With a little time and patience for her to decompress, she will blossom. I could see her fitting into the pack of a family with kids or as a sidekick for a single person. She doesn't have much leash manners, and can pull many directions to keep sniffing. But occasionally she would look back and she was so excited to see me and leaned in for pets. She doesn't know basic commands like sit, etc. however she seems eager to listen and is very curious. She was not reactive on the leash when we say from afar people, dogs, wheels (scooters, skateboards, etc). She didn't bark or growl or show any kind of aggression. No signs of pancaking during the walk. She's sooo gentle with taking snacks and playing with her toys. I gave her a bath and she was amazing. So patient and not afraid at all. She gently nibbled on fries in the tub or playing with the squeaky toy and was totally calm. She loved the toweling off and was even okay with a little bit of the blower to dry her. We took a car ride back to the shelter. She did okay with me in the backseat of the car, but was very wriggly. I don't think she's used to riding in the car. With practice I think she'll settle down more and be comfortable. Hoping once she gets into a routine, she'll settle down and build confidence.

pets.summaryHtml:

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Bentley
pets.summaryHtml:
MEET BENTLEY!
Bentley was brought to ACC when his former family could no longer care for him. He's now looking for a fresh start with someone who understands big dogs with big feelings.

MY IDEAL HOME
An experienced, adult-only home that can provide structure, patience, and positive reinforcement training. Bentley does best with a quiet environment and slow, consistent introductions. A home outside the city or with a private yard would be ideal.

GOOD WITH KIDS?
Recommended adult-only due to his fear-based behavior and touch sensitivity.

GOOD WITH OTHER PETS?
Limited history. In shelter playgroups, Bentley has been nervous and defensive around other dogs. He may be best as the only pet. Cats: unknown.

LEASH MANNERS
Bentley can be strong on leash and alert-barks at people and dogs. He is working on leash manners with a front-clip harness, treat-based engagement, and pattern games to help him stay focused.

OVERALL HEALTH
Bentley is a young adult, vaccinated, microchipped, and will be neutered prior to adoption. He recently recovered from a common upper respiratory infection.

BEHAVIOR DETERMINATION
Level 3 - Bentley is a fearful, handling-sensitive dog who warms up with familiar handlers. He needs decompression, slow exposure to new things, and force-free training to build confidence. No children under 13.

OTHER FUN FACTS
Bentley enjoys squeaky toys, soft blankets, and gentle attention from people he trusts. He may take time to open up, but once he does, he's affectionate and loyal. Bentley is ready to leave the shelter behind and find his person.

Bentley can be strong on leash and alert-barks at people and dogs. He is working on leash manners with a front-clip harness, treat-based engagement, and pattern games to help him stay focused.

OVERALL HEALTH
Bentley is a young adult, vaccinated, microchipped, and will be neutered prior to adoption. He recently recovered from a common upper respiratory infection.

BEHAVIOR DETERMINATION
Level 3 - Bentley is a fearful, handling-sensitive dog who warms up with familiar handlers. He needs decompression, slow exposure to new things, and force-free training to build confidence. No children under 13.

OTHER FUN FACTS
Bentley enjoys squeaky toys, soft blankets, and gentle attention from people he trusts. He may take time to open up, but once he does, he's affectionate and loyal. Bentley is ready to leave the shelter behind and find his person.
pets.description:
MEET BENTLEY!
Bentley was brought to ACC when his former family could no longer care for him. He's now looking for a fresh start with someone who understands big dogs with big feelings.

MY IDEAL HOME
An experienced, adult-only home that can provide structure, patience, and positive reinforcement training. Bentley does best with a quiet environment and slow, consistent introductions. A home outside the city or with a private yard would be ideal.

GOOD WITH KIDS?
Recommended adult-only due to his fear-based behavior and touch sensitivity.

GOOD WITH OTHER PETS?
Limited history. In shelter playgroups, Bentley has been nervous and defensive around other dogs. He may be best as the only pet. Cats: unknown.

LEASH MANNERS
Bentley can be strong on leash and alert-barks at people and dogs. He is working on leash manners with a front-clip harness, treat-based engagement, and pattern games to help him stay focused.

OVERALL HEALTH

BEHAVIOR DETERMINATION

OTHER FUN FACTS
Bentley enjoys squeaky toys, soft blankets, and gentle attention from people he trusts. He may take time to open up, but once he does, he's affectionate and loyal. Bentley is ready to leave the shelter behind and find his person.

pets.name: Bigs
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Bigs is on the at-risk list due to behavior concerns. Bigs has displayed a high level defensiveness in the care center, including growling, baring teeth, hard barking, and lunging during leashing attempts. He often becomes tense at the kennel door, showing reactive behavior when some staff step closer to greet him. Bigs is aloof with staff during interactions, engaging minimally. Medically, Bigs is diagnosed with CIRDC. Bigs came into the care center as a stray; due to this, his behavior in a home environment is unknown. Bigs has shown signs of denfensive behavior, particularly at the kennel front. He has had multiple incidents of growling, hard barking, baring teeth, and attempting to bite when handlers attempt to leash him. On several occasions, he has retreated to the back of the kennel and lunged at the leash when approached, requiring handlers to discontinue attempts and allow him time to decompress. Outside the kennel, Bigs is able to walk on leash with a slightly tense body and shows improved behavior once out of the highly arousing kennel environment. During structured sessions, he has demonstrated the ability to engage with handlers, eat tossed treats, remain calm after settling, and even offer behaviors such as "down" on cue. Bigs will require a New Hope placement experienced with fear-based and defensive kennel aggression who can offer a calm environment with low pressure, structured decompression, and positive reinforcement-based handling.

pets.name: Bingo
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

pets.name: Biscuit
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I am finding the shelter a little overwhelming, but when it's just you and me and some peace and quiet you'll see what a love bug I am.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

pets.name: Blu
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Blue Baloo
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Blue Baloo arrived at the Care Center as an owner surrender due to housing concerns. His previous owner described him as a friendly and outgoing; also very high energy. During his stay, Blue Baloo has been social and treat motivated with staff. Recently however, he is showing concerning poor impulse control and signs of social hyperarousal. Blue Baloo as been observed to persistently jump on handlers and at times pushes off staff with his front paws. This is most prevalent during walks. While he is treat motivated, he is not consistently able to be redirected. We recommend placement with an experienced New Hope Partner that can help manage his behavior with positive, force free handling.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

My boroughbreaker writes:Blue was super interested in the lakes and seems like he likes to swim. He also absolutely loved fetch and chewing the ball after. It seems like he would love chew toys. He was such a sweetheart and was so social and so full of love. Blue was also amazing with snacks he never snatched them and always waited for them to be given and took them out of my hand so gently. He's very strong but wasn't lunging he just liked to move fast and was very interested in squirrels. He was occasionally interested in other dogs in a playful way. Blue also had tons of energy and even after walking for hours he was happy to run / walk more. Also I didn't check the box for I listen to commands because I didn't try any but he responds to his name well and sat for treats every time. He also did great on stairs. Blue will truly brighten someone's home and life. A Volunteer Wrote: This might make you cry, but you don't have time because you need to RUN to adopt this dog who has lived with cats, dogs, and kids: When asked about Baloo, his previous owner said, "I love him with my whole soul and am so glad I got to be his owner, even if it wasn't forever." We are honoring them both while Baloo is at the shelter by showering this playful, friendly baby with love, and it is the lightest lift given that he is the giver of endless kisses and tail wags, especially when belly rubs are involved. We would be so thrilled if you would take over as his new devoted owner, this time forever!

pets.name: Blue Shell
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Blue is a loveable grandpa, who deserves a forever home filled with love, cuddles and plenty of peanut butter! This lovebug loves a soft surface - comfy dog bed, couch or human bed - to rest and wants nothing more than to be with his humans. Like any land seal, he loves his baked potato time - laying in the sun outside and watching the world go by is one of his favorite pastimes. He's calm on a leash, house trained, makes the funniest whale noises when he wants attention and is comfortable both in your presence and when left home alone. He'd do best in a home with no stairs, but goofy Blue would give his forever family lots of kisses and laughs!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I am a sweet, social, older gentleman, looking for the perfect forever home!

pets.name: Blues Clues
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Blues Clues!

Blues Clues is a six-year-old medium mixed breed with a big personality and an even bigger heart. She's a 56-pound bundle of bounces, wiggles, and affectionate energy who's been patiently waiting for someone to see past the shelter stress and into her goofy, lovable soul. Found as a stray and now fully vetted and spayed, Blues Clues is ready to put her detective skills to good use sniffing out snacks, toys, and a forever home.

My foster writes: Looking for a cuddly and low-key dog- Blues Clue is for you! This 6 year old gem is the perfect lady, respectful at home and happy to doze away on the couch or in a pile of pillows- even better if she has a blanket to keep her cozy! As an adult, she is relatively low energy and content with 2 easy walks and maybe some fun toy play but that's about it! With that routine, she has shown to be fully house-trained which is a great skill to have in an apartment. She does show some reactivity to dogs and some wheeled items but is super food motivated. Since we have had her, she will easily let dogs walk by her with the reward of a nice piece of chicken so the behavior is very easy to manage even during busy times of day. We have loved having her in our home and know she will make a wonderful pet for anyone who is looking for a easy-going companion!

My foster writes: Meet Blue's Clues - the strong diva with the cutest puppy dog eyes you've ever seen!
She spends her days trying to collect cuddles from every single person she walks past, clearly a lover girl at heart. Blue's Clues is great with humans and has amazing intuition. She really gets you and understands what you're telling her, which makes her a total joy to have around.
Playtime is a non-negotiable in her world. Toss the toy once, and you've just signed up for a lifetime of fetch, she'll never let you forget how much fun it is!
She's respectful of boundaries and knows the rules. In our apartment, she understands she's only allowed on one bed, and she sticks to it, no couch surfing or room sneaking here!
Blue's Clues is ready for her forever home, with just one simple requirement: a safe, loving space and at least one bed (or couch!) she can call her own. Are you ready to fall in love?

My foster writes: Blue is the best friend you've been looking for. She'll cuddle you when you're down, protect you and keep you company. She'd thrive in a one dog household. She loves going for walks and playing with her toys. You don't have to worry about blue being home alone- she is very respectful of her humans stuff. She's house trained and will let you know if she has to go outside. She's also good with children.

My foster writes: Blue is the best friend you've been looking for. She'll cuddle you when you're down, protect you and keep you company. She'd thrive in a one dog household. She loves going for walks and playing with her toys. You don't have to worry about blue being home alone- she is very respectful of her humans stuff. She's house trained and will let you know if she has to go outside. She's also good with children.

pets.name: Bonnie
pets.summaryHtml: Bonnie arrived at MACC as a stray with no known history. During intake Bonnie was obsvered to hard bark and lunge towards another dog. While in care Bonnie has continued to show this level of reactivity. Observed to hard stare towards dogs and people while on leash. In the kennel room Bonnie is obsvered to pull hard towards the other kennel while hard barking and growling. Bonnie has also been obsvered to be fearful with handlers. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home that make no trips to the dog park.

pets.name: Bonsai
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have been known to shower my favorite people in love!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

A volunteer writes: I had the pleasure of hanging out with Bonsai at the recent ACC adoption event sponsored by Best Friends Animal Society. The weather was a bit chilly and overcast. Bonsai behaved well throughout the entire event. Bonsai happily greeted everyone (adults and kids) who then reciprocated with lots of pets and loves. Bonsai was eager to show off his skills - perfect sit, treat catching and waiting patiently for a treat left a short distance away until I said "ok, go get it". Between meeting the people, Bonsai and I took nice leisurely walks and spent time cuddling up under the blankets. Bonsai is a playful, active, sweet and loving boy. He can be chilled when needed. Bonsai walks nicely on leash. He can pull a little when he is interested in something, but he can be easily redirected and continues his walk. Bonsai definitely loves to play and to spend time with his person. Go and meet Bonsai. He is really a good, good boy who just wants to enjoy life with someone into the future.

pets.name: Bougie
pets.summaryHtml:
Bougie is the most gentle, loving and affectionate dog I have ever met. She has the energy the accompany you on walks wherever you want to go but will just as happily sit and snuggle with you on the couch. She is the biggest cuddle bug in the world and wants to be next to (or on!) you whenever you're on the couch. She is very food motivated which makes practising commands very easy and she is a quick learner. Her forever family will be so lucky to have her and she will give you all her love from the second she meets you. She is perfect in the house, quiet, potty trained and shows no destructive tendencies. She is the sweetest little girl and so easy to love!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I am finding the shelter a bit overwhelming. Outside one-on-one I am a great big cuddle bug.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

pets.name: Brock
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

My foster writes: This sweet 8-year-old pitty is a certified cuddle pro who's happiest when he's by your side-or napping nearby. Low energy and laid-back, Brock is the perfect Netflix-and-snack companion (especially if treats are involved-he lives for those). He's a good boy who listens well and loves long walks when it's time to stretch those legs. Another foster writes: Brock is the mush ball of your dreams! This easy-going older gentleman loves naps, cuddles, and treats of all kinds. He's happiest when he's near his people, getting butt scratches and belly rubs. He naps like a champ but can be left alone to do his own thing. This hungry, hungry hippo will do anything for a treat, but has good table manners for a food-motivated good boy. He's a dream on the leash, walking next to you with ease as he explores the neighborhood. Brock's charm is obvious to everyone on the street - he gets constant compliments when he's out. He loves nothing more than cuddling on the couch with you at the end of the day. This sweet angel is a big boy with an even bigger heart and would love to nuzzle you to the ends of the earth. Another foster writes: Brock is the sweetest older gentleman who just wants to hang out and be near his people. He's super sweet, super chill, and the perfect buddy for lazy days, short walks, and snack breaks. He's also a really good listener, knowing tons of commands like sit, stay, and lay down, and he's currently learning "up" and "drop it" like a total pro. Brock has great leash manners, does fine on his own when you're out, and melts hearts everywhere he goes with his big head and soft eyes. He's not needy, just happy to be nearby, whether you're watching TV, working from home, or just relaxing. If you're looking for a low-key, lovable sidekick who's all about comfort, cuddles, and good company, Brock's your guy!

pets.name: Brownstone
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Brownstone arrived at the care center as an owner surrender. Brownstone has a history of growling when his food bowl is approached. In the care center he has escalated to growling and lunging during handling and has shown clear signs of discomfort when interactions feel intrusive. Brownstone becomes tense in unfamiliar situations and avoids engagement when he is uncomfortable. Brownstone is also described as social and affectionate in calmer contexts, seeking proximity to people when he feels safe. As a result, we recommend he is placed with one of our New Hope Partners.

pets.name: Bruno
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

Bruno is a strong and spirited pup in our Shelter Scholars program, working to improve his responses to on-leash triggers. Through engagement games, focused leash handling, and exposure to controlled situations, Bruno is learning to pause, think, and stay connected with his handler. His determination is driving real growth.

pets.name: Bull
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I need a home where there are no other pets.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I would prefer someone who can be home with me most of the time.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

A volunteer writes: Bull is just a little guy. His weight is listed at 50 pounds but he is much more of a lap sized guy - which he proves easily in the yard. He quickly dons his PJS and makes his way onto my lap, not really willing to get off of it, preferring cuddles to the rainy grass. He was initially found as a stray tied up in lower Manhattan. He was adopted but returned when the family did not think he was a good fit. Unsurprisingly based on his initial shyness, Bull has been spooked by children and large crowds. Bull has preferred to keep space from other dogs. He enjoys car rides, long walks and baths! Ask to meet him today!

pets.name: Bun Bun
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Bun Bun is on the at-risk list due to behavior concerns. Bun Bun has shown high arousal and difficulty with handling in the care center, frequently trying to push out out of his kennel, jumping repeatedly on handlers, and struggling to settle during walks or training sessions. He has also been reactive to other dogs at a distance. When returning to his kennel, Bun Bun often balks, thrashes, or attempts to bolt back out, requiring coaxing or food lures to secure him safely. Medically, Bun Bun is apparently healthy.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am playful and cute!

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

Bun Bun is 40 pounds of pure fun. Truly, I don't think I've ever seen a dog zoomie around with such gusto. Show him a toy and you'll see his eyes instantly light up with joy - an infectious, joy that makes him irresistible to be around. Equal to his passion for toys (he is indiscriminate: stuffed toys, balls, and squeaky rubber ones are all fair game) is his love of cuddling up to any human in his line of sight. In between bouts of puppy-like energy (he is, of course, barely a year old and has lots of it), he sidles up for affection, and his body wiggles and tail wags happily when I scratch his back. He has such a bright spirit. Run, don't walk, to meet this sweet, active, happy young boy.

Medically, Bun Bun is apparently healthy. What my friends at ACC say about me: My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet! It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children. I am playful and cute! I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy. Bun Bun is 40 pounds of pure fun. Truly, I don't think I've ever seen a dog zoomie around with such gusto. Show him a toy and you'll see his eyes instantly light up with joy - an infectious, joy that makes him irresistible to be around. Equal to his passion for toys (he is indiscriminate: stuffed toys, balls, and squeaky rubber ones are all fair game) is his love of cuddling up to any human in his line of sight. In between bouts of puppy-like energy (he is, of course, barely a year old and has lots of it), he sidles up for affection, and his body wiggles and tail wags happily when I scratch his back. He has such a bright spirit. Run, don't walk, to meet this sweet, active, happy young boy.

pets.name: Cali
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

Cali is a bright and determined dog enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, working on feeling more comfortable and confident around food. With a clear structure and lots of positive reinforcement, she's discovering that calm behavior brings great rewards. Her journey is well underway, and she's showing excellent focus in training.

pets.name: Candy
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Candy was surrendered to the care center by her owner due to a no-pet policy in their home.Candy is a highly fearful and handling-sensitive dog who has shown significant panic and avoidance behaviors since intake. Upon arrival, she presented with a tense body, tucked tail, and repeatedly attempted to flee. While on leash, she pancaked and thrashed intermittently as she was brought to medical. During her exam, Candy remained anxious and resistant to handling, vocalizing and attempting to escape. When approached for procedures, including muzzle attempts, she escalated to lunging and snapping. Despite her fearfulness, Candy did show the ability to wam up to selective handlers. She will require a patient, experienced New Hope partner that can provide slow, low-pressure handling, structured decompression, and a predictable environment to help her feel safe and build trust. Candy is available for rescue through one of our new hope partners.

pets.name: Caramel Toffee
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

Due to a scratch incident I require a little extra paperwork to be filled out and a few extra vet visits this year). A Volunteer Wrote: This adorable girl is the embodiment of delight: even in the pouring rain, she's psyched to be outside, and she's even happier to be wet because it means she gets to be dried off and get more attention! Caramel, who shows no reactivity to dogs on a walk, has quickly become a volunteer favorite thanks to her enormous charm and easy companionship. Please come meet her at Manhattan!

pets.name: Carlos
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

pets.name: Casentino
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

A volunteer writes: Casentino has long been on my "Extra TLC" list - getting extra walks (even more important since he's been very housebroken); extra treats; and extra attention. Why? Well, because when Casentino arrived, he was so stressed, he couldn't focus on anything. He pulled hard and directionless on our walks, never stopping to sniff, and having no interest in anything - not toys, balls, treats, squeakers, or pets. But now Casentino is a much different pup! I usually find him comfortably resting on his bed, and as I unlock his kennel, he happily yet calmly steps off his bed, does a little back stretch, then leisurely walks up to the door with a soft body and waggy tail. Being in a much better state of mind, he's also been revealing more about himself - like how he loves treats, knows "sit", gets wiggly when I baby-talk him, and has a budding interest in toys. I also love that he's been enjoying pets, if only briefly; though I think with time, he'll get comfortable with more prolonged touching. If Casentino can come this far in a stressful shelter environment, I can only imagine how much more he'll blossom in a loving home.

pets.name: Cash
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Cash arrived at the QUACC as an owner surrender. Cash has been intensely fearful in the care center, often shutting down and holding as still as possible, but will approach staff with a slow approach. His previous owners described him as a social and affectionate dog who is very active, playful, and vocal but prefers contact on his own terms.

pets.name: Cedar
pets.summaryHtml:
There is an adorable video of me on ACC's Instagram page. Click here to experience the cuteness!



My foster writes: Are you ready to welcome a bundle of happiness into your life? Look no further, because Cedar is here to steal your heart and fill your days with endless joy! This lovable companion is eagerly waiting to find her forever home, and she's bound to be the perfect addition to any family. Cedar's incredible demeanor makes her an ideal companion for all your daily adventures. Housebroken and well-mannered, she understands the rules and won't jump up on furniture, ensuring a seamless transition into your home. Her favorite game is a spirited game of tug, and you'll find immense joy in sharing these playful moments with her. Cedar's crate training adds an extra layer of convenience to her adaptable nature. Whether you're working from home or heading out for errands, she's content and secure in her crate. And speaking of working from home, Cedar is the ultimate coworker. She's more than happy to snooze by your feet as you work, providing both companionship and comfort. Strolls around the neighborhood are a true delight with Cedar by your side. She approaches walks with a leisurely pace, savoring every moment and taking in all the captivating scents along the way. Her curiosity and appreciation for the world around her are a constant reminder to find joy in life's simple pleasures. Cedar's endearing qualities have won the hearts of everyone she meets, making her a favorite among shelter volunteers. Her unwavering spirit and genuine affection make her an exceptional companion that's ready to fill your life with happiness. Don't miss your chance to adopt Cedar and make her a cherished member of your family. Her playful antics, loving nature, and heartwarming presence are sure to bring a smile to your face every day. Cedar is the ultimate couch potato and professional snuggler. She could spend the whole day curled up next to you while you catch up on your favorite shows or get lost in a good book. She's a total homebody-happy with a couple of short walks, a game of tug, and plenty of treats. She's also housebroken and, despite being a bit of a big girl, does just fine in smaller spaces as long as she's with her people. Cedar is super low-maintenance and totally okay being left alone, so you won't have to worry about coming home to a disaster. Instead, you'll be greeted by a happy pup who's just excited you're back. She's incredibly loving once she knows you, but she can be a little shy with new people. She needs slow introductions and a little patience, but once she trusts you, she's all in. Cedar tends to feel more comfortable around female-presenting folks, though she has made a few exceptions, usually for people with lots of love (and treats) to offer.

pets.name: Champ
pets.summaryHtml:
There is an adorable video of me on ACC's TikTok page. Click here to experience the cuteness!
My foster writes: Champ is a bundle of love! He can't wait to snuggle up and pass out on your lap after a good kissing and licking session! He loves people and is easy to be around. Very well mannered and easy going guy. He can work on being around other dogs and after he's found his forever home his anxiety will likely subside as well. He's a one of a kind dog overall! My foster writes: Champ is, well, a Champion of many things. But above all - he is a champion cuddler. A crowned cuddle king, who will literally leave a bowl of food behind if it means he has a chance to snuggle next to you and get a belly rub. He loves so deeply and unrelentingly, even shortly after you meet him - he'll gaze at you with soulful eyes and lick your face if you let him. Champ seizes any chance to love and be loved by his human. He's like a heated and weighted blanket combo, ready to comfort you. Champ has a huge heart that matches his huge head. He's smarty (of course his head is so big, it holds his smarts!) - he picks up on training cues quickly, whether working on his tolerance for being left alone (can you fault a shelter dog for wanting to be by your side?) or teaching him to "check in" with you on a walk (say "look at me Champ!" And he'll glance back with a big goofy smile). He's learning leash manners with positive reinforcement and clicker/treat training. When he hears the click and gets it right, he stamps excitedly and smiles, awaiting his "good boy!" Followed by a treat. This Champ doesn't need a cheerleader but if you want to see him do his stamp, wide-smile victory dance, definitely cheer for him! He seems to trust humans more readily than other dogs, but with the right dog and slow introduction, Champ might also love a canine friend - but he's fully content just being with his human. He sleeps through the night, even when he's not next to you. But I'm sure he'd prefer to be by your side. He's also a great ride-along boy, hanging (and sometimes sleeping) quietly in the backseat with his seat belt buckled. Potty trained and not destructive when left alone, Champ is a solidly wonderful boy whose love and devotion are so unrelenting, you'll wonder how you ever got so lucky to be his friend. Dogs with Level 2 determinations are believed to be suitable for adopters with some previous dog experience. They will have displayed behavior in the shelter (or have owner-reported behavior) that requires some training, behavior management or modification. Dogs with a Level 2 determination may have multiple potential challenges and these may be presenting at differing levels of intensity, so careful consideration

There is an adorable video of me on ACC's TikTok page. Click here to experience the cuteness!
My foster writes: Champ is a bundle of love! He can't wait to snuggle up and pass out on your lap after a good kissing and licking session! He loves people and is easy to be around. Very well mannered and easy going guy. He can work on being around other dogs and after he's found his forever home his anxiety will likely subside as well. He's a one of a kind dog overall! My foster writes: Champ is, well, a Champion of many things. But above all - he is a champion cuddler. A crowned cuddle king, who will literally leave a bowl of food behind if it means he has a chance to snuggle next to you and get a belly rub. He loves so deeply and unrelentingly, even shortly after you meet him - he'll gaze at you with soulful eyes and lick your face if you let him. Champ seizes any chance to love and be loved by his human. He's like a heated and weighted blanket combo, ready to comfort you. Champ has a huge heart that matches his huge head. He's smarty (of course his head is so big, it holds his smarts!) - he picks up on training cues quickly, whether working on his tolerance for being left alone (can you fault a shelter dog for wanting to be by your side?) or teaching him to "check in" with you on a walk (say "look at me Champ!" And he'll glance back with a big goofy smile). He's learning leash manners with positive reinforcement and clicker/treat training. When he hears the click and gets it right, he stamps excitedly and smiles, awaiting his "good boy!" Followed by a treat. This Champ doesn't need a cheerleader but if you want to see him do his stamp, wide-smile victory dance, definitely cheer for him! He seems to trust humans more readily than other dogs, but with the right dog and slow introduction, Champ might also love a canine friend - but he's fully content just being with his human. He sleeps through the night, even when he's not next to you. But I'm sure he'd prefer to be by your side. He's also a great ride-along boy, hanging (and sometimes sleeping) quietly in the backseat with his seat belt buckled. Potty trained and not destructive when left alone, Champ is a solidly wonderful boy whose love and devotion are so unrelenting, you'll wonder how you ever got so lucky to be his friend. Dogs with Level 2 determinations are believed to be suitable for adopters with some previous dog experience. They will have displayed behavior in the shelter (or have owner-reported behavior) that requires some training, behavior management or modification. Dogs with a Level 2 determination may have multiple potential challenges and these may be presenting at differing levels of intensity, so careful consideration

pets.name: Chase
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have lived with dogs in my previous home.

I lived with children in my previous home.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Cheeto
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Cheeto arrived at the Care Center as an owner surrender due to housing concerns. Cheeto was noted to be aloof with handlers, and lean in for soft contact during a handling assessment. Recently Cheeto has become difficult to handle safely on leash. Cheeto is noted to baulk hard, thrash, and use his paws to push away from the kennel entrance with escalating intensity. With staff Cheeto continues to be aloof and treat motivated when outside on walks. We recommend placement with an experienced New Hope Partner.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

pets.name: Chewy
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Chewy arrived at the Care Center as an owner surrender, his previous owner describes him as playful and outgoing. Chewy has been showing a concerning low-threshold for arousal during his stay. He has been observed to be persistently leash biting, jumping on handlers, and panting when in the presence of people. These behaviors have been difficult to redirect. We recommend placement with an Experienced New Hope Partner in an adult only home.

pets.name: Choco Pie
pets.summaryHtml:
There is an adorable video of me on social media! Click here to experience the cuteness!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

My foster writes: Just like his name, Choco Pie is all sweetness with a marshmallowy center. He's a total lovebug who wants nothing more than to be by your side-especially if you're handing out chest rubs. Taking a break from work? Great, he's already there, giving you those big eyes that say, "Is it cuddle o'clock yet?" He's a pro on the leash (with the occasional detour when an interesting smell crosses his path), but overall, he's got that walk game down. Plop yourself on the floor, and Choco Pie will politely trot over and sit like a gentleman, just close enough to make sure you notice how soft his head and chest are. Within seconds, all decorum vanishes-flop!-he's on his back, legs in the air, inviting you to pets on his chest, sides, squishy neck folds, and under his chin. Also, you will definitely want to. He's brave and confident when you're around, but being alone still makes him a little anxious. He's working on it, though, and with some patience and gentle training, he'll learn to be more confident and independent. If you're looking for a loyal shadow with a heart as soft as a marshmallow center, Choco Pie is your perfect treat. My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Chocolate was very chill from the start, met us begging for belly rubs and happily walked over to the park. We walked some trails then stopped under a shady tree - chocolate loved lounging with us even more than walking!

pets.name: Christmas
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Christmas has displayed concerning levels of defensive aggression during previous stays in care as well as poor bite inhibition, he has mouthed handlers and escalated to snapping in the past as well as leash biting. Christmas also has a concerning bite history in his previous home due to resource guarding and handling sensitivity. Aside from this Christmas is reported to walk well outside on the street and does not show signs of reactivity during walks. We recommend placement with a New Hope rescue partner who is able to provide an experienced, adult-only foster home. Force-free, reward based training and/or consultation with a professional trainer/behaviorist is highly recommended.

pets.name: Chrysanthemum
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

An apt name for a beautiful girl, Chrysanthemum has blossomed during her stay at the shelter. Shy and a little overwhelmed by the smells and sounds of the shelter at first, her confidence has grown exponentially, and she's always eager to go on a walk when she sees me at her kennel, happily hopping off her bed to greet me. On walks, she's delightful, checking in with me along the way, and she's even been known to stop and smell some flowers! (She asked me if I could change her name to a flower she could spell, but I told her she could go by "Chris" or "Mum" if that was easier and she seemed satisfied.) She's been waiting far too long for her forever family to spot her - in a sea of tan and white pittie-type pups, she may be easy to overlook, sitting quietly in her kennel, but she'll make the sweetest companion to whoever gives her a chance. Chrysanthemum is a smart and independent pup working on resource guarding with toys as part of her Shelter Scholars training. She's learning through guided exercises and enrichment activities that toys don't need to be protected and that cooperation brings even more fun. Her growth in trust and confidence is already shining through.
