pets.name: Laguardia
pets.summaryHtml:
There is an adorable video of me on social media! Click here to experience the cuteness!
Meet **LaGuardia** ✈️-no delays, just naps! This sweet, low-maintenance girl is a professional snoozer who happily supervises the home or office from the comfort of her dog bed. She greets every human like an old friend, belly up and ready for head scratches, and has zero interest in chewing, barking, jumping on people or causing trouble. Her quirks? She's still learning that walks are for strolling, not shouting at other animals. She's also not the biggest fan of peanut butter or stairs (though she'll put up with both if she has to). Give her a crunchy snack, preferably plant-based-watermelon cubes, green beans, cabbage, cucumber, you name it-and she'll be your biggest fan. LaGuardia's motto: **nap hard, snack often, love everyone.** 🐾💤 My ideal home A calm, adult-only home that will give LGA time to decompress and continue positive-reinforcement training. She's easy-going inside, enjoys meeting new people, and thrives with a predictable routine, enrichment (sniffy walks, food puzzles), and lots of cuddle breaks. Adult-only (no children under 13). LGA is working on her confidence and can be uncomfortable around high-energy environments. LGA can become tense around other dogs on leash and has shown kennel reactivity. She may do best as the only pet while she builds skills.(Cats: unknown.) Leash Manners: Polite walker at your side once she settles in. When she sees other dogs, she may get stiff and focused; treats, distance, and a front-clip harness help her reset. She's learning check-ins and responds to patient, reward-based guidance. LGA is affectionate and leans in for pets-she simply needs consistent, kind coaching to feel secure. Her foster calls her a "sweet, loving mush" who will lounge near you all day. She has a signature move: the "apple alert." Bite into one and she'll appear with the cutest face, politely asking for a taste. She is easy-going and calm, and loves meeting new people as long as they're willing to give her some pets. LGA has a lot of love My foster writes: Let little LaGuardia love you! This perfect-sized munchkin wants nothing more than to snuggle and give kisses. A chill, low-energy dog, LGA doesn't need much in her golden years. While she does ask everyone to pay the cheese tax, really all that she wants is a quiet home, a comfy couch to lie on, and someone to be her favorite person to make her a happy girl!

pets.name: Lake
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Little Red
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Little Red is on the at-risk list due to behavior concerns. Little Red has shown a high level of fearfulness in the care center, repeatedly hard barking, growling, lunging, and baring teeth when approached. During leashing attempts, she dodges leashes, jumps toward handlers' hands, making it difficult to handle her safely at times. Outside the kennel, she remains tense and low-bodied with a tucked tail, pacing and showing conflicted behavior, leaning in for touch while her skin rippling when touched. Medically, Little Red is receiving treatment for CIRDC. Little Red came into the care center as a stray due to this her behavior in a home environment is unknown. Little Red was transported to the care center in a crate, and officers noted that when the crate was moved, she began growling and biting at the door. On intake, Little Red was shut down and highly fearful, requiring staff to allow her to exit the crate by tilting it rather than through direct handling. In the care center, she continues to display stress signals such as growling and baring her teeth when approached in her kennel. Little Red will require a New Hope rescue placement experienced with fearful dogs who display potential for defensive aggression. She will benefit from a slow, decompression-based approach, minimal handling pressure, and positive reinforcement techniques.

pets.name: Load O' Potatoes
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Load O' Potatoes!
Found as a stray and brought to the 90th Precinct before coming to ACC, this affectionate city walker is ready to trade kennel noise for cozy naps and neighborhood strolls. Volunteers rave about her sweet manners and cuddle game on BoroughBreaks.

My Ideal Home
An experienced, adult-only home that offers calm structure, patience, and a thoughtful decompression plan. Routine sniffy walks, enrichment (food puzzles, long-lasting chews), and reward-based training will help her shine. A front-clip harness and clear, consistent cues set her up for success.

Good with Kids?
Recommended adult-only (no children under 13) based on shelter observations and behavior team guidance.

Good with Other Pets?
Best as the only dog for now. In the busy kennel room she can be reactive (barking/lunging), but outdoors-with space and support-she often passes dogs without fuss. No dog parks. If you have a resident dog, plan slow, structured introductions with professional guidance. Potatoes needs a home without cats or small animals.

Leash Manners
Often a loose, thoughtful walker who checks in with her handler. If excited, she may briefly grab the leash; this has been easy to redirect with treats or a squeaker. She's tolerant of gentle petting during walk breaks and navigates sidewalks well when supported.

Overall Health
Spayed. Vet team notes dental tartar; regular dental care, balanced diet, and everyday exercise will help her feel her best. Previously had a shelter cough that resolved. (Your vet can personalize her wellness plan once home.)

Behavior Determination & Other
ACC Behavior Level: 3
Recommendations: Adult-only; no dog parks; front-clip harness; reward-based training to build focus around other dogs. In kennel/play-yard settings she may react toward neighboring dogs; on the street, distance and support help her stay composed.

Fun Facts
Her BoroughBreak buddies called her "an absolute angel" with "paw-tastic manners." Car-ride comfy, picnic-ready, generous with kisses, and a champion at settling after a good walk.

Ready to meet Load O' Potatoes?
If you love training, structure, and cuddly couch time-and you're ready to be her safe landing-Lo's your girl.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Lo was an absolute angel and pawtastic! She was very well-behaved and had great manners. She is very sweet and gave loads of kisses! She was never hesitant and was always ready for the next adventure!

A Volunteer Wrote: I first met her flat on her back. She had thrown herself down, in a fit of pleasure, on the sidewalk, and was scratching her back on the cement and wriggling around and wagging her tail, while her borough break buddy looked equally delighted. "She's just the best!" she reported in on her morning with our girl. She's endlessly affectionate, has fantastic manners, and is adored by all of us because she's been here long enough for us all to fall in love. Please--come break her out, once and for all, and let the back scratches begin!

If you love training, structure, and cuddly couch time-and you're ready to be her safe landing-Lo's your girl.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Lo was an absolute angel and pawtastic! She was very well-behaved and had great manners. She is very sweet and gave loads of kisses! She was never hesitant and was always ready for the next adventure!

A Volunteer Wrote: I first met her flat on her back. She had thrown herself down, in a fit of pleasure, on the sidewalk, and was scratching her back on the cement and wriggling around and wagging her tail, while her borough break buddy looked equally delighted. "She's just the best!" she reported in on her morning with our girl. She's endlessly affectionate, has fantastic manners, and is adored by all of us because she's been here long enough for us all to fall in love. Please--come break her out, once and for all, and let the back scratches begin!

pets.name: Logan
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

pets.name: Logan
pets.summaryHtml:
🐾 Meet Logan! 🐾

Logan is a handsome 2-year-old pup with a big personality and an even bigger love for toys! He came to us as a stray with the police, and since then, he's been showing off his playful, energetic side every day. Soft toys are his absolute favorite-he loves to toss, chase, and sometimes tear them to shreds in pure joy!

Logan is an independent guy who enjoys his playtime and does best when given space while he's enjoying his toys, as he can show a bit of resource guarding. Once he's had his fun and burned off some energy, Logan reveals his sweet, affectionate side with staff.

This clever boy is very food-motivated, which makes training both fun and rewarding-though he can take treats a little enthusiastically at times!

We think Logan would do best in an adult home with no other pets at this time, where he can have consistent guidance, structure, and plenty of love. He would thrive with an experienced owner who can continue his training and help him build confidence.

pets.name: Loki
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have never lived with other animals or children.

I love getting pets!

I am a sweet, social, older gentleman, looking for the perfect forever home!

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

Loki's Foster says: Loki is an 11 year old, handsome, loyal companion. He is easy going & loves to go on walks. He has perfect bathroom skills--not one accident in my house. Loki gives many kisses & likes to be petted. He will be a great addition to some lucky person's family.

pets.name: Loyal
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Loyal!
Surrendered to ACC when apartment life and noise complaints became too stressful, Loyal is a bright, bouncy pup who loves people and wants to be wherever you are. He comes out wiggly, learns fast with treats, and is happiest when his brain and body are busy.

My Ideal Home
I'll thrive with experienced adopters in a calm, low-traffic home. I'm a high-energy, eager learner who benefits from structure, enrichment (sniff walks, food puzzles, "find it"), and positive-reinforcement training. Because alone time has been hard for me, I'll do best with someone home often at first and a gradual plan to build my confidence when solo.

Good with Kids?
Adults only. I can be jumpy and take treats with hard pressure when excited, so no children under 13 while I polish my manners.

Good with Other Pets?
I alert-bark and may lunge toward dogs (especially small dogs) on walks, and I notice small animals. I'd do best as the only pet to start. If you have a resident dog, plan very slow, well-managed introductions. No known cat history.

Leash Manners
I pull with enthusiasm and may fixate on dogs, but I respond nicely to reward-based games (check-ins, "1-2-3," engage/disengage). A front-clip harness, clear routines, and consistent reinforcement help me settle into a looser leash.

Overall Health
Healthy overall. Recently neutered and recovering well. Had a brief tummy upset that resolved, and I'm being treated/monitored for a mild kennel cough. Staff will review simple next steps with you.

Behavior Determination
Level 3 - Adults Only. I'm social and playful but need help with impulse control, mouthy treat-taking, leash reactivity, and separation anxiety. I'll shine with positive-reinforcement training, decompression time, and predictable routines.

Other Fun Facts
I greet with a full-body wiggle, love working for snacks, and learn quickly when training is fun. If you're looking for a high-spirited roommate to adventure with-and to coach into his best manners-I'm your guy.

pets.name: Lucy
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: I had the pleasure of fostering Lucy for a few days, and let me tell you, this girl is an absolute gem. She's a wonderful blend of energetic explorer and devoted couch potato, and she's sure to bring so much joy to the right family.  Lucy is incredibly affectionate. My favorite moments were our quiet mornings, sipping coffee while she dozed off for a cuddle. She loves nothing more than snuggling up on your lap or resting her head on your arm in the evening. She's a gentle soul who will let you play with her ears and takes treats from your hand with the softest mouth. Lucy is a fantastic walking companion! She has a natural enthusiasm for other dogs and is very eager to greet and play with them some day. She also has a quirky love for high places and will seek out am elevated ledge to survey her kingdom. She adorably also is scared of escalators!  Like any smart and energetic dog, Lucy is still learning her manners. She has so much love to give and will reward her new family with endless snuggles and unwavering loyalty. She is a lovable little angel who truly deserves a patient, loving forever home. My foster writes: Lucy is a wonderful girl with a sweet, puppylike nature. She adores humans, so much so that when you first meet Lucy, she will greet you with high-energy enthusiasm, but she's a champion snuggler at heart. Her perfect evening is a movie night after day with lots of walks, tucked right next to you, ideally with a peanut butter Kong for a snack. While she's still learning tricks and cues, Lucy is smart and curious and eager to please, making her a great student for training. Lucy is also endearingly clumsy! She doesn't always know where her legs are, which leads to the occasional trip and tumble, and it makes getting in and out of the car or up onto the couch an awfully cute spectacle. Her biggest dream is to finally get to play in a dog park! Lucy deserves the world and will make a fantastic family member.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

pets.name: Luffy
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

A Volunteer Wrote: Luffy was beloved by his former owner, who said he was playful and friendly with the child with whom he lived, as well as unknown children; the same went with other dogs and humans of all kinds. Luffy is winning hearts here, as well; despite being in a pop up crate against the wall, he makes friends by offering kisses through the bars until someone relents and plays with him. Luffy is looking for his forever playmate and a life not lived in a crate--please come meet him!

pets.name: Luna
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

A Volunteer Wrote: If you're looking for a dog to tap dance her way into your heart, Luna will do so in the time that it takes to leash her up-she literally dances with joy just at the thought of getting some love! And you will be so eager to offer it up: volunteers call her "sweet" so many times we might lack imagination, although we also praise her leash manners and adoration of treats. You know what her biggest treat would be? A forever person (or people) for whom she could keep showing off her dance moves!

pets.name: Madame Jenny
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: MJ is a sweet, silly, and incredibly affectionate dog who has been a cherished part of my life for the past year. She's smart, playful, and always ready to bring joy to those around her. I'm constantly amazed by how much love she has to give-not just to me, but to everyone she meets. She's grown into a confident and social senior pup, always excited to make new friends, both human and furry. She gets along well with other dogs and even cats, as long as she's introduced to them at her own pace. While she can be a little cautious with strangers at first, it never takes long for her warm and loving nature to shine through. One of MJ's most special traits is her intuition. She always seems to know when I need comfort, whether I'm feeling down or just in need of a little extra affection. Her playful energy is infectious, whether she's eagerly playing tug-of-war or trotting happily beside me on a walk.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

pets.name: Marge
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster wrote: Marge is a dog that is just truly enjoyable to be around. I can't say it more plainly than that! She is fun, energetic, cuddly, smart, and really is a good girl who wants to learn and do the right thing! Going on this adventure together, developing trust, and watching her blossom into the smart, confident, bird watcher (hunter wannabe), that she is has been amazing! She's such a friendly, funny, sweet dog who loves to be loved and shower everyone with that love. She adores her pup cups at the cafe on Saturday mornings, almost as much as her pup cups at her Friday night happy hours. At both, she is the epitome of polite patience, although she will expect some additional bites of pizza or olive oil cake for that patience. She has never gotten aggressive with any dog or loud noise passing by either. When left alone, she may have an accident at first if she's scared, but building up trust with Marge is essential. Once that trust is built, it's there forever and she'll try to never have an accident inside again, even if she has to be alone on the 4th of July! On leash, Marge walks like the supermodel she was born to be. She rarely pulls and will stroll leisurely and stop to smell flowers (or the occasional bag of trash). She does love a road snack though, so being attentive is a must because this gal will scarf down an old piece chicken faster than you can say drop it! Speaking of food, this lady literally jumps for joy at dinner time and it cracks us up everyday. If you work from home, you'll have a new office mate who snores and will randomly bring you socks sometimes. She never chews them, just finds them near the hamper and gently leaves them on your lap or holds them right by you and waits for you to take it. Only socks, nothing else. I call them her offerings. I can go on and on, but in the end, Marge is a quirky, fun, dog and deserves the best quirky, fun, New Yorker to be her forever friend! So come meet Margarina Moss, supermodel of dogs and see for yourself!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Mars
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

A Volunteer Wrote: Someone has drawn hearts near Mars' name on the walking log and it doesn't take long to see why: he's a delight! In the park he's absolutely lovely with other dogs around, even ignoring three little barkers who come at him. He's happy to show off his acrobatic finesse hopping on a picnic table (!) and he's equally happy to sit snuggling on a park bench. This goofy, sweet boy is a great dog waiting for a wonderful home to call his own.

pets.name: Matilda
pets.summaryHtml:
💗 Meet Matilda! 💗

Matilda is a beautiful 3-year-old sweetheart who was found running as a stray, showing signs she had recently been a mama. Despite her rough start, this loving girl's gentle and affectionate spirit shines through.

Matilda absolutely adores attention and will happily soak up all the love you have to give-especially if treats are involved! Snacks are her favorite, and they're a great way to earn her trust and help her feel comfortable.

It seems Matilda may not have had much training or guidance in the past, but she's eager to learn and will thrive in a patient, understanding home that can give her the time and space to decompress.

This special girl has already shown so much resilience and sweetness. She truly deserves the very best forever home-one filled with kindness, stability, and plenty of cuddles.

pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

pets.name: Melvin
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Melvin is at risk due to behavioral reason. When Melvin arrived he was observed to be highly fearful noted to hard bark, growl, bare teeth when handlers approach. Recently Melvin has begun turning in kennel, biting and tugging the leash into kennel. This behavior is not able to be redirected easily. Medically, Melvin is receiving treatment for CIRDC.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

pets.name: Mika
pets.summaryHtml:
Hi! My name is Mika! Here's what my friends at ACC say about me:

My foster writes: Mika is a very loving and sweet dog. She wants nothing more than to lay with you on the couch or bed and snuggle up to you or to bring her ball to you and play. She has been learning to walk nicely on the leash and absolutely loves being outside. She is friendly to people and kids and greets everyone with her tail wagging. Mika does snore when she sleeps and can even snore when she's awake! She takes treats very gently and knows how to sit, stay or give paw for treats. She will benefit from plenty of exercise, food puzzles and interaction with you. She should be the only pet in the home and, because of her strength and excitability, a home with no small children. My foster writes: If I had to describe Mika in a single word, it would be exuberant! She is a joyful and loving companion who wants to become friends with every living creature she meets. While she is certainly energetic she is also equally cuddly, and is happy following a good round of exercise with cuddling close on the sofa to watch a show. She's also so eager to please that she learns quickly, having picked up several new commands with minimal effort. She would be certain to brighten any home she enters!

Mika is a fun-loving pup who loves to explore her surroundings. She is still adjusting to being around other dogs, cats, and squirrels, and is working on her leash manners. Mika has a lot of energy and would benefit from a patient, experienced owner who can help her reach her full potential. With the right home, Mika could thrive and become a loyal companion

My ideal home: Mika will succeed in an experienced home without tiny humans or other animals.

pets.name: Minnie
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Minnie came into the care center as a stray due to this her behavioral history in a home environment is unknown. Minnie came into the care center as a stray due to this her behavioral history in a home environment is unknown. Minnie is a fearful, touch-sensitive dog who consistently displays tense body language, a tucked tail, whale eyes, and lip licking during interactions. While she will approach handlers and gently take treats, she quickly becomes conflicted and stiffens, indicating discomfort with close contact. She tolerates soft handling but shows clear stress signals throughout. Minnie will benefit from a patient, low-pressure environment that allows her to build trust at her own pace. She is available for rescue through one of our new hope partners.

pets.description: This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response. Pre-Screener Form Minnie came into the care center as a stray due to this her behavioral history in a home environment is unknown. Minnie came into the care center as a stray due to this her behavioral history in a home environment is unknown. Minnie is a fearful, touch-sensitive dog who consistently displays tense body language, a tucked tail, whale eyes, and lip licking during interactions. While she will approach handlers and gently take treats, she quickly becomes conflicted and stiffens, indicating discomfort with close contact. She tolerates soft handling but shows clear stress signals throughout. Minnie will benefit from a patient, low-pressure environment that allows her to build trust at her own pace. She is available for rescue through one of our new hope partners.

pets.name: Miss Missy
pets.summaryHtml:
Miss Missy is a bright and enthusiastic pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's working on developing better manners and learning how to engage with the world in a polite and thoughtful way. Through structured enrichment, confidence-building exercises, and stress-reducing activities, Miss Missy is practicing skills like polite greetings, patience, and calm interactions. Using positive reinforcement training, she's making great strides in learning when to engage, when to wait, and how to respond to exciting situations with grace! My previous foster writes: Miss Missy has been such a pleasure to have in my home. She is a very sweet loving girl that enjoys butt rubs, head rubs and giving the occasional wet kiss on my cheek! She loves to lounge on the couch for her naps or rest her head in my lap while we watch tv. Occasionally when Miss Missy is feeling a little bossy; she'll take her nose and pick my hand up to give her some head rubs! She even knows cues such as sit, lay down and paw. This wonderful lil lady is also house trained and has never gone potty inside. This is my first time fostering and Miss Missy has been a delight and the ideal dog! A Volunteer writes: Miss Missy will woo you with her affection and adorable habit of sitting on cue for treats. She knows "sit" and "paw" and, at just over a year old, has so much potential to learn more in a foster or forever home! An easy walker, even for new volunteers, she loves exploring on long walks and sometimes rolls in the grass. This silly girl has even been spotted snoring in her kennel. As one of the shelter's long-timers, she dreams of a real home to snooze in. For now, Miss Missy should be the only pet. My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Miss Missy was a very good girl! A few things I noticed on our walk was she was reactive to other dogs, car sounds, and men specifically, and a bit of a leash puller. She's a very strong girl! She took her treats well and liked to lean her weight into us. Next time I will hope to take her indoors and get to socialize with her more as she was a little overwhelmed and on alert at all times with her surroundings outside.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: We took a nice car ride, she enthusiastically explored the apartment smelling where all the dogs had been before but quickly settled in to watching me make some lunch, we played with dog toys and snuggled on the sofa and gave lots of kisses. She was immediately VERY affectionate wanting pets, belly rubs and cuddles. We took a nice nap on the sofa together and then played some more. She has the SOFTEST most velvety ears.' My adoption fee has been sponsored thanks to a generous donor!

pets.name: Missy
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Missy!
Missy was brought to us as an owner surrender and is a delightful, social butterfly. She loves being in the presence of family and strangers alike, showing off her friendly and outgoing nature.

My Ideal Home
Missy will thrive in an adult-only home where she can enjoy a calm environment. A household familiar with managing medium energy levels would suit her well, ensuring she gets her daily walks and the affection she adores. A place without children or cats is ideal, as well as a family that understands her on-leash reactivity and can provide positive reinforcement.

Good with Kids?
No, Missy is not comfortable around children and may react with barking or growling. An adult-only home is recommended.

Good with Other Pets?
Missy prefers to avoid other dogs and is not suited for a home with cats, as she may react to them with barking or growling. She thrives best in a pet-free environment.

Leash Manners
Missy walks well on a leash with minimal pulling, though she might react to dogs and strangers approaching her by barking or growling. Regular walks and continued leash training would benefit her greatly.

Overall Health
Healthy overall.

Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters Only: Missy needs a home where her resource guarding can be managed, and her potential for defensive behavior around children, dogs, and unfamiliar situations can be addressed with understanding and care.

Other Fun Facts
Missy is incredibly affectionate and thoroughly loves attention and hugs! She is treat motivated, with bacon being a particular favorite. Missy enjoys car rides and relaxing with her people, making her a wonderful companion for those cozy evenings at home.

pets.name: Mist
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Misty
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Misty is an extremely special dog. She has the biggest heart and wears it on her sleeve. She is excited to meet every person and every dog, she loves treats, and sleeps like a champ (I often have to wake her up myself to start the day!). She has no separation anxiety and greets you at the door with one of her stuffies, just excited to see you. She has no stranger danger and doesn't bark (except on rare occasions when she really wants to play with a dog who isn't interested in her!). She's an absolute delight. There is an adorable video of me on social media! Click here to experience the cuteness!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Misty is the sweetest, most gentle soul you'll ever have the pleasure of walking. I had the joy of taking her out on a BoroughBreak, and she was an absolute delight from start to finish. Calm and loving, Misty walked beautifully on leash, never pulling-just enjoying the sunshine and soft breeze with quiet grace. She lit up for treats and gave the warmest tail wags to everyone we passed. Misty was wonderfully composed around other dogs, showing only friendly interest and a desire to play. She's a true family dog-great with kids, affectionate with people, and full of that soft, steady energy that makes a house feel like home. If you're looking for a loyal companion with a heart full of love and a peaceful spirit, Misty is the girl for you. Let her be your sunshine every day. 🌞🐾 A volunteer writes: Misty is exactly our type. A 10 year old senior grandma, with lots of spunk. She's ready for mall walking, 4 pm happy hours, and adult only resort vacations. She has ears that always lean to her left. Misty was found loose in a Kissena Park in Queens with a leash and collar but no owner in sight. When we meet Misty, she hops right into the pool. She's not wasting any time outside on this warm day, and gently splishes and splashes while she cools off. After she finishes her swim time, Misty plops down with a stuffed piggie in the yard. Misty will need some medical follow up for a few masses she has. She is clearly a delight and a bright light that deserves to shine for whatever time she has left.

pets.name: Moochie
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Moochie is a snuggler! Sitting on the floor putting your shoes on for her walk? She may make it challenging by trying to sit on your lap. Sitting on a chair? She may climb part way up and embrace you, leaning in for rubs, trying to get her whole body onto your lap. Settling in on the couch? She'll eagerly join you. Moochie is a sweetheart friendly with all the humans she encounters, whether or not they have treats (though she does love treats).

A Volunteer Wrote: Moochie was so devoted to the cat she used to live with that she would sleep beside him at night, happily snoring away. She lived just as sweetly with two children, reveling in her toys, baths, and car rides, and her former owner says that her friendly, outgoing personality extends to other dogs, as well! In other words, this charming girl is the perfect company. As her former owner was surrendering Moochie, she said, "She doesn't like to be alone." It's painful to think that while Moochie is waiting patiently, we know that her former family is gone forever. We're so hoping she isn't waiting too long to become the newest member of her forever family!

pets.name: Mr. Smith
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Mr. Smith!
Mr. Smith arrived at our care center as a stray, so his past is a mystery. Despite this, he's proven to be a charming fellow who enjoys human company. With a soft, sleek coat and gentle eyes, Mr. Smith is both handsome and affectionate. He's known for leaning into petting and giving his full attention to those nearby. My Ideal Home
Mr. Smith would thrive in an adult-only home with an experienced owner who is familiar with large dogs. A calm, quiet environment where he can relax and feel secure would be best. His new family should be prepared to invest time in his training and daily exercise. Good with Kids?
No. Due to his reactivity and size, Mr. Smith is best suited for a home without children under 13. Good with Other Pets?
Mr. Smith has shown reactivity towards other dogs and should be the only pet in the household. He would do best without cats or small animals. Leash Manners
Mr. Smith is a strong, enthusiastic walker who pulls quite hard on the leash. Training with a front-clip harness or head halter, along with positive reinforcement techniques, would greatly benefit him. Overall Health
Healthy overall with no known medical issues. Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters - Mr. Smith requires a patient owner willing to work on his training and manage his anxiety with gentle guidance. Other Fun Facts
Mr. Smith loves to engage with people and enjoys mental challenges like puzzle toys and hide-and-seek games. He's sensitive and shy but blossoms with patience and care.

pets.name: Mudskipper
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Mudskipper is at risk due to behavioral concerns. Mudskipper arrived at the Care Center as a stray with no known history. Mudskipper was noted to be tolerant of staff and allow handling. Shortly after his arrival, Mudskipper has been showing concerning handling sensitivity and defensive behaviors that have made it difficult to handle him safely. When returning to kennel, Mudskipper was reported to thrash with escalating intensity, snapping at the leash, pushing off the wall in kennel room, and requiring the aid of a secondary handler. Mudskipper has at times been treat motivated, and limited sociability with staff. Medically, Mudskipper is noted have dental disease, otitis externa, and be overweight. Shortly after arriving at the care centers, Mudskipper has begun to display concerning levels of defensive aggression and refusal to re-enter kennel after walks. He was observed to thrash and snap at handlers when attempting to return him and belly band him to kennel. While in kennel Mudskipper has displayed socail behavior, seeking interaction with handlers with a soft body. We recommend placement with a New Hope rescue partner who is able to provide an experienced, adult-only foster home. Force-free, reward based training and/or consultation with a professional trainer/behaviorist is highly recommended.

pets.name: Murph
pets.summaryHtml:
Murph is a thoughtful and sensitive pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where he's learning to regulate his energy through relaxation protocols. With the help of techniques like mat work, Murph is gaining the ability to settle in new or stimulating environments. He's showing steady progress as he builds confidence and calm.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Nala
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I am a sweet, social, older gal, looking for the perfect forever home!

I can be slow to adjust to new environments. I prefer to take things at my own pace.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I am finding the shelter a bit overwhelming. Outside one-on-one I am a great big cuddle bug.

pets.name: Narnia
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

My foster writes: Narnia's love and affection will melt your heart. Her favorite place is cuddled up next to you on the couch, and she will follow you room to room wherever you go. She loves to play tug of war, and she has a big goofy personality that'll make you laugh. She'll have short bursts of playful energy, but she's also totally content to curl up on the couch throughout the day. She also makes the cutest little grunts/snorts when she's happily eating. Other things to note: - She's housebroken (will only go to the bathroom outside or on the wee wee pad if necessary). - She's great with meeting new people in a calm setting. - She loves peanut butter and cheese. - She is obsessed with squirrels and will scan every tree and bush to look for them. - She barks occasionally but is easily shushed. - She sleeps well in her crate as long as it's near you, and she is happy to sleep in with you. - She would probably be best with someone who works from home, as she doesn't enjoy being left on her own. She would be such a joy for any person or family!! My boroughbreaker writes: We had the best time with Miss Narnia! She was playful and affectionate! She warmed up to us pretty quickly and was such a silly, wonderful dog! Things to know about Narnia: - She has the softest fur ever. It is like silk and velvet combined. - She has a lot of fun and sweet energy! I think she would do well with a home where she has space to get her zoomies out! - She LOVES squirrels. Once she sees one, she is locked in. Things Narnia loves: - Cheese (a past boroughbreak walker said she wasn't food motivated, but with cheese she definitely seemed to be! She quickly learned sit and she started doing paw!) - Somersaults. She loves to roll on top of you head first! It is the cutest thing! - Rubbing her body on your legs and furniture. She's like a cat in that way! - Icecubes.she had a blast playing with ice cubes, moving them around the floor and eating them haha. Things Narnia may need help with: - Pulling on leash - Feeling safe and comfy in new places - once we got to my apartment she was fighting sleep, any little noise would wake her up! But once she got settled (which was pretty quickly) she finally let herself rest.

pets.name: Nina
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Nina was returned to MACC following a bite incident. Nina became over aroused during a walk and began jumping up, mouthing them, and tugging on their sleeve. This resulted in a wound that bled. During her previous stay int he care center, Nina was fearful and on leash reactive. During her current stay Nina is noted to have a very low threshold for arousal. During her assessment Nina was running around the room grabbing different objects. Due to the detailed behavior we recommend an experienced adult only home. My foster writes: Nina is a 4-year-old, 64-lb sweetheart who strikes the perfect balance between playful and cozy. She enjoys her walks and will happily trot along, but her true passion is curling up on the couch for a good nap or snuggle session. She's also a big fan of people-watching-give her a balcony or a window and she'll happily hang out, watching the world go by like it's her favorite show. She's been known to fall asleep flat on her back with her paws in the air and snore like she owns the place! On walks, Nina lies down when she sees other dogs because she really wants to say hello. She's non-reactive and has shown nothing but friendliness so far, though her foster home hasn't officially tested her with other pets. She's also learned to communicate when she needs to go out and is making great progress with potty training as she adjusts to home life. Nina isn't a fan of the crate-but she doesn't need one! She's quiet, gentle, and non-destructive when left to relax freely. One of her sweetest quirks is "corncobbing" and gently sucking on her blanket or stuffed animal to self-soothe-she never destroys them, just cuddles and comforts herself. She's a smart girl who already knows sit, stay, come, off, and leave it. She may get a little bouncy when she's excited and sometimes jumps to say hi, but she's eager to please and takes direction well. Nina would thrive in a home that gives her affection (but gives her space until she's ready for it!), daily walks, a comfy spot to snooze, and a good window or balcony to supervise her neighborhood. If you're looking for a loving, goofy, low-maintenance companion with a heart of gold, Nina might just be your perfect match. Nina is a bright and determined pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's working on managing on-leash reactivity and developing more calm, confident walking habits. Through positive reinforcement training, focused leash work, and enrichment activities, Nina is learning how to stay connected with her handler and respond to distractions in a more thoughtful way. She's making steady progress and growing more comfortable with each session.

pets.name: Nova
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am looking for a home with a patient person.

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Nubi
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Nubi (or Nubby as I call her) is a sweet gem of a dog. She is quick to trust her person and full of love and kisses for them. She is fully potty trained and is well behaved in the apartment. She has a favorite blanket and a favorite spot on the couch that I have had to fully surrender to her. Nubby loves to play with her stuffies, she loves to shake them into submission, and enjoys our training sessions, showing that she is quick to learn. Nubby is working on her leash skills and she needs someone who is willing to go slowly with her and help her to build her confidence in new situations and when outside.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

A Volunteer Wrote: We love, love, love this dog with all of our hearts. So many of us have praised her sweetness (she offers kisses even through the bars of her pop up crate), her adoration of scratches when she leans into you, and her gratitude at being given treats. Her former owner reports she's lived with kids, is fine with other dogs, and loves to play. We hate that she's not getting a chance to do that in an overcrowded shelter when she should be playing tug of war (her favorite) or sleeping on a couch. This is a girl with so much love to offer, and it's a privilege to do for such a gentle soul. Please come meet her!

pets.name: Obie
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

Please check here for updated adoption hours.

My foster writes: I am the puppiest pup in world. most excited about... well. everything. everywhere. always. I am fantastically curious and determined to explore. When not focused on strategic sniffing I might get carried away chatting awkwardly right at other dogs to unsuccessfully explain how much I would like to play though I do not understand societal rules. I am the most excellent lounging buddy and also easily excitable with loads of energy. My sudden jolts of wonder could be challenging for those unfamiliar with spastic strong and sneakily quick pups. I love to run together and chase after those taunting squirrels... and shadows. and suspicious inanimate objects. I am very interested in learning games and tricks. I could use someone with a quickness and strength who is able to sense my moves and catch me right away and someone active and into taking me everywhere. I am the perfect adventurous best friend.

pets.name: One Bunzy
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes; This sweet girl is friendly, gentle, and full of love. She adores meeting new people and animals alike - she'll happily rest her head on your knee for some cuddles. Bunzy is smart, eager to please, and seems easy to train. She has a calm, loving nature and a beautiful face that will melt your heart. Whether you're going for a walk or relaxing at home, Bunzy just wants to be by your side, sharing love and joy every step of the way.

pets.name: Orbot
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Orbot!
Brought to ACC as a found dog, Orbot has the calm, thoughtful vibe of a seasoned companion. He walks politely, accepts gentle pets, and takes treats with care. Shelter life makes him a little anxious in his kennel, but once he's out, he shows you his easygoing side and a soft spot for snacks.

My Ideal Home
I'll do best with patient adopters who can offer a quiet space, predictable routines, and plenty of reassurance while I decompress from the shelter. Give me unhurried walks, comfy naps, and simple enrichment (sniffy strolls, food puzzles), and I'll settle in nicely.

Good with Kids?
Best without very young children. I can vocalize in my kennel when stressed and prefer a calm, gentle approach; dog-savvy older kids/teens could be a fit after a meet-and-greet.

Good with Other Pets?
We don't have a known history. My dog-to-dog interactions here are inconclusive, so slow, supervised introductions are recommended if you have resident pets.

Leash Manners
Polite and steady. I walk ahead without pulling, follow along nicely, and check in for treats like a gentleman.

Overall Health
Healthy overall with a brief stress-tummy episode that's being supported with simple care. Heartworm test negative. The shelter vet issued a spay/neuter waiver due to surgical risk in a shelter setting; your vet can advise about any future procedures.

Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters (Level 3): I'm easy to handle out of the kennel but can bark or growl when stressed in the kennel environment. With a low-key home, positive reinforcement, and time to decompress, I'm set up to thrive.

Other Fun Facts
I'm food-motivated (canned food and... a little SPAM, please), take treats gently, and love a calm stroll. If you're looking for a wise, well-mannered buddy to share the quiet moments, I'm your guy. A Volunteer Wrote: The only thing sadder than seeing an older dog in the shelter (when he might be living out his days in a loving home) is seeing an older dog who seems so defeated by it all. Orbot has the most perfect manners with all he comes into contact with, and has the sweetest face and disposition, but he's not coming into contact with people the way he so deserves. If you have spare room on your couch, Orbot is just waiting to be loved back to life!

pets.name: Ozzy Pawsborne
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Ozzy Pawsborne is at risk due to behavioral concerns. Ozzy Pawsborne arrived at the Care Center as a stray with no known history. Upon intake Ozzy Pawsborne was loose bodied, treat motivated and allowed all handling. Despite efforts to keep him comfortable, Ozzy Pawsborne has shown concerning on-leash reactivity to dogs, signs of low-threshold for arousal and deterioration. When on walks Ozzy Pawsborne has been observed to hard stare, pull towards dogs, with raised hackles, and is difficult to redirect. During handling assessments Ozzy Pawsborne was reported to jumb on staff, and head-whip with an open mouth. Although not consistent, Ozzy Pawsborne has been noted to be spinning and bark persistently in kennel. With Staff, Ozzy Pawsborne continues to be social and treat motivated. Medically, Ozzy Pawsborne is noted to have a metal object in her chest just under the skin based on Xrays taken object is suspected to be potentially a bb gun pellet/bullet, removal is recommended if being combined with another medical procedure in the future. Ozzy Pawsborne is otherwise apparently healthy.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

A Volunteer Wrote: This winning brindle boy can't decide whether he wants an adventure (he loves to run around!) or he wants to sneak in kisses, but if he can run around and then sneak in kisses, he's very, very happy. Ozzy is affectionate and kind and has an energy level where he would absolutely thrive not living in a kennel all day, minus walks. We would so love to see him doing zoomies around your backyard and then curling up next to you on the couch. Please give him the chance to do both!

pets.name: Penny
pets.summaryHtml:
Penny is a sweet, shy girl who melts into a total mush once she feels safe. She is playful, loves attention, and is a true fashion girly who rocks everything from wigs to unicorn horns. She may be named Penny but she is worth every penny and one of the last pennies you will ever want to let go of. Come meet her at Queens ACC or share to help her find her furever home. My boroughbreaker writes:Penny is the sweetest girl! She loved meeting new people, getting excited and a little jumpy. She was quite reactive when seeing other dogs while on leash, jumping and running around me (she's pretty strong), but as we spent more time together i was better able to help her calm down. She overall did really well walking on the leash in the streets. Over time she became more responsive to me and very trusting. She responded to sit and down commands. Once we got to my apartment, she was curious and sniffed around where she could, and was super snuggly with me, even climbing into my lap :) Not sure if she's fully house trained, but in the time we spent at my apartment she didn't have any accidents and i think she let me know when she needed to go out.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Pepper
pets.summaryHtml:
The foster writes :
Pepper is a loving, loyal pup in search of her forever family. She enjoys lazy days chilling inside as well as adventuring in nature. Pepper is completely housebroken (potty trained and does not destroy things). However, she does love playing with her toys! Pepper also loves food and learning new things for treats. But what Pepper loves most is napping on the couch next to her person! 

Pepper is currently being fostered in a busy neighborhood in Queens, but would much prefer a quieter setting. Pepper needs to be the only pet in the home. Other dogs make Pepper nervous. Her foster has been working on this and Pepper is improving with redirecting her attention back to her handler. She also knows basic commands and is food motivated/ eager to learn. Once she knows the routine, she is okay with staying home alone as long as she knows you will be back in time to give her dinner!

Pepper loves her people but likes slow introductions to strangers. Once she feels comfortable with a person, she is the most loving and loyal pup and enjoys belly rubs and ear scratches. Since entering ACC, she has lived in 3 different foster homes and has adored all of her fosters but desperately wants a forever family!

pets.name: Pepper
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Pepper arrived at the care center as an owner surrender. Pepper has a history of growling when her food bowl is approached. In the care center she has escalated to growling and lunging during handling and has shown clear signs of discomfort when interactions feel intrusive. Pepper becomes tense in unfamiliar situations and avoids engagement when she is uncomfortable. Pepper is also described as social and affectionate in calmer contexts, seeking proximity to people when she feels safe. As a result, we recommend she is placed with one of our New Hope Partners.

pets.name: Pepsi
pets.summaryHtml:
Another foster writes: Pepsi is so sweet and affectionate. She loves to be around her humans and is a quick learner. She does have some behavioral issues on a leash, only when people are walking by or she sees other dogs. She is so excited to meet everyone on the street but is fearful and aggressive towards other dogs. However, I see much improvement from when she first came home with me. My foster writes: Meet Pepsi! 🐶✨ This 4-year-old fizzy ball of love is sweet, silly, and always ready for snuggles. Pepsi's favorite activities include zoomies in the yard, awkwardly trying to sit on your lap (she thinks she's tiny), and giving you the world's goofiest grin. She's got the heart of a teddy bear and the energy of a soda can just cracked open. Looking for a loyal best friend with a soft side and a playful spirit? Pepsi is your girl. 🖤🐾 #AdoptPepsi

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Perry
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Perry Beary! Perry is the sweetest, most adorable pup in the world! She is more than happy to nap next to you while you work at home or help you decompress after a long day with playtime and good walks. If you let her, Perry is more than happy to join you for cuddles on the couch, but she is very respectful, so if you don't feel like a 70lb cuddle monster is on the agenda today, she's more than happy to hang out on her own bed or in her crate. Perry loves fetch and food in equal amounts, so she's pretty easy to please. Potty trained and mild-mannered, Perry is the best! My temporary foster writes: Perry knows many commands and is learning command "let go" when ever she grabs the leash. She doesn't have leash reactivity. She doesn't pull while on walks. Has no reactivity to dogs and if curious she may focus a bit but not fixated and can be redirected by a small tug of her leash and the command "focus". She also has no reactivity to humans adults or little ones. She also has no reactivity to stray cats which we have many in our neighborhood.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Phynx
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Phynx is at risk due to behavioral concerns. Phynx arrived at the Care Center as an own surrender. Her previous owner noted that Phynx is sweet, social, playful, and also crate trained. Despite efforts to keep Phynx comfortable, she has been showing concerning levels of reactivity. When being taken for walks, Phynx has been persistently trying to kennel fight and pull hard toward occupied pop-up crates. She has also shown on-leash reactivity on the street, pulling towards dogs, tense body, and is difficult to redirect. Phynx has been social with select staff, allowing petting and treat motivated. Medically, Phynx is being treated for unspecified dermatitis and CIRDC.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

A Volunteer Wrote: We have a circus girl in the house! As one staff member who knows her says, "This one's a good doggy," but what we couldn't anticipate is all the tricks she has ready to show off: sit, paw, other paw, standing on her back legs on command...wowza! She's lived in a home with kids, and her former owner describes her as "playful and friendly" with strangers and other dogs. We second and third that-Phynx is amazing across the board.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

pets.name: Platypus
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: (I've been calling him Hammy not Platypus) Hammy is a social butterfly who loves people, treats, and dog friends. At home, Hammy wants to be as close to his humans as possible, and is the perfect size lap dog at just 45 lbs (and that's mostly his blocky head!). He's completely house-trained, loves to play with squeaky toys, and can be left home alone for several hours without issue. A boy whose tail never stops wagging, Hammy is happiest when he's with his people getting all the attention he deserves.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am playful and cute!

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

A Volunteer Wrote: Even Platypus' "formal" notes include the words "wagging tail," because this boy's tail is always wagging, even when he's in his kennel. He's as easy with his kisses and hugs as he is on a leash, likes treats and loves pets. Another volunteer calls him "engaging and enchanting," which are indeed the perfect descriptors!

pets.name: Pond
pets.summaryHtml:
Pond is an observant and energetic pup in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's developing the tools to manage on-leash reactivity. Using redirection techniques and engagement cues, she's practicing how to stay calm and responsive, even when other dogs are nearby. With consistency, Pond is learning that walks can be relaxing and fun. Meet Pond!
Found as a stray and brought to ACC, Pond is a wiggly, people-loving sweetheart who thinks belly rubs are a sport and laps are seats made just for her. She's playful, affectionate, and eager to bond once she's had a moment to decompress from the shelter bustle.

My Ideal Home
I'll thrive with patient, experienced adopters who enjoy training games and structure. A calm, adult household that can help me settle in, build confidence, and keep my brain busy with fun enrichment (sniff walks, food puzzles, "find it" games) will help me be my best self.

Good with Kids?
Best in an adults-only home. I can get overstimulated with handling and am still learning that vet/handling moments are safe, so no children under 13 for me right now.

Good with Other Pets?
I've shown mixed feelings around dogs-sometimes playful, sometimes barky or tense. I'd do best as the only dog to start, or with very slow, thoughtful introductions to a well-matched, calm dog. No known cat history.

Leash Manners
I start out excited and can pull, but I'm responding nicely to reward-based games like "1-2-3," "take a breath," and engage/disengage. With consistency, I settle into a looser leash and offer great check-ins. I'm a quick study when you make training fun!

Overall Health
Healthy overall. I had a brief bout of kennel-stress tummy upset that resolved and I'm doing well with normal care and monitoring.

Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters (Level 3 - Adults Only). I'm social and cuddly with my people but can be sensitive with handling and reactive around some dogs. Positive-reinforcement training, clear routines, and gradual confidence-building will set me up to succeed.

Other Fun Facts
I greet friends with a whole-body wiggle, roll over for belly rubs, and will happily toss toys for myself when the zoomies hit. I'm the perfect combo of playtime pal and cuddle buddy-ready to splash into my next chapter with you.

Leash Manners
I start out excited and can pull, but I'm responding nicely to reward-based games like "1-2-3," "take a breath," and engage/disengage. With consistency, I settle into a looser leash and offer great check-ins. I'm a quick study when you make training fun!

Overall Health
Healthy overall. I had a brief bout of kennel-stress tummy upset that resolved and I'm doing well with normal care and monitoring.

Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters (Level 3 - Adults Only). I'm social and cuddly with my people but can be sensitive with handling and reactive around some dogs. Positive-reinforcement training, clear routines, and gradual confidence-building will set me up to succeed.

Other Fun Facts
I greet friends with a whole-body wiggle, roll over for belly rubs, and will happily toss toys for myself when the zoomies hit. I'm the perfect combo of playtime pal and cuddle buddy-ready to splash into my next chapter with you.
pets.description: Pond is an observant and energetic pup in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's developing the tools to manage on-leash reactivity. Using redirection techniques and engagement cues, she's practicing how to stay calm and responsive, even when other dogs are nearby. With consistency, Pond is learning that walks can be relaxing and fun. Meet Pond! Found as a stray and brought to ACC, Pond is a wiggly, people-loving sweetheart who thinks belly rubs are a sport and laps are seats made just for her. She's playful, affectionate, and eager to bond once she's had a moment to decompress from the shelter bustle. My Ideal Home I'll thrive with patient, experienced adopters who enjoy training games and structure. A calm, adult household that can help me settle in, build confidence, and keep my brain busy with fun enrichment (sniff walks, food puzzles, "find it" games) will help me be my best self. Good with Kids? Best in an adults-only home. I can get overstimulated with handling and am still learning that vet/handling moments are safe, so no children under 13 for me right now. Good with Other Pets? I've shown mixed feelings around dogs-sometimes playful, sometimes barky or tense. I'd do best as the only dog to start, or with very slow, thoughtful introductions to a well-matched, calm dog. No known cat history. Leash Manners I start out excited and can pull, but I'm responding nicely to reward-based games like "1-2-3," "take a breath," and engage/disengage. With consistency, I settle into a looser leash and offer great check-ins. I'm a quick study when you make training fun! Overall Health Healthy overall. I had a brief bout of kennel-stress tummy upset that resolved and I'm doing well with normal care and monitoring. Behavior Determination Experienced Adopters (Level 3 - Adults Only). I'm social and cuddly with my people but can be sensitive with handling and reactive around some dogs. Positive-reinforcement training, clear routines, and gradual confidence-building will set me up to succeed. Other Fun Facts I greet friends with a whole-body wiggle, roll over for belly rubs, and will happily toss toys for myself when the zoomies hit. I'm the perfect combo of playtime pal and cuddle buddy-ready to splash into my next chapter with you.

pets.name: Poptart
pets.summaryHtml:
My Foster writes: Poptart is a beautiful dog inside and out. He is very loyal and loves to be pet. He tells you how much he enjoys your touch by leaning into your legs or giving you his belly. He acts more like a nervous puppy, despite his sleek and confident look. He flops about when he returns a ball or toy during fetch, as if he is trying to throw it himself. He will lean in against you when he is nervous but treats and lots of "good boys" does the trick to calm him down. In many ways he is a homebody as he likes the comfort and safety of being with you in a quiet environment with people he trusts. He is not a couch potato, rather he lets you do you while he enjoys his chew toys. He has certain behaviors that tell you he needs to go out to relieve himself and listens well to commands like heel, sit and stay. If he gets a little zany, he is telling you he needs to go out. Once he's finished his business (a short or long walk does the trick) he will settle in for a cozy nap or some serious puzzle toy/treat. My foster writes: My name is Poptart for good reason! Just like the pastry I will fill you up with sweetness on the inside and my beautiful caramel, cinnamon color on the outside. I'm a two-year-old boy who loves walking or running - you set the pace and I will follow. I'm eager to learn more tricks and will do anything for a treat! Toss me a biscuit, a bone, a piece of carrot or apple and I will heel, sit and come right to your side. Just click your tongue and you have my attention! Even a squirrel can't compete for my attention if there's a treat in your hand. I am learning manners around other dogs and people, so I would do best with someone who doesn't have a dog at home and who can teach me good manners and new tricks. I also love my chew toys and can keep myself busy, but if you have a free hand I am always up for a good head scratch, which leads to a back scratch and that soft white furry spot under my chin hairs! I will tell you if I need to go out by standing at the door or pushing my nose into you. I would make an excellent companion but if you have kids, my energy level would be best pared with older kids who will play with me. I would thrive in a home where I'm included in daily activities and given lots of love, especially hugs! I love those! If you're looking for a loyal, affectionate and energetic companion to grow old with, then I've been looking for you too!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

pets.name: Prince Charming
pets.summaryHtml:
**Meet Prince Charming!**
Prince Charming was surrendered to ACC when his owner moved into an apartment that doesn't allow pets. With a name like his, it's no surprise this five-year-old brindle boy has a lot of heart-and a lot of energy. Loyal, sensitive, and super smart, Prince Charming is hoping to find a family who will help him channel his enthusiasm and give him the structure and love he craves.

---

**My ideal home:**
Prince Charming is looking for an experienced adult-only home where he can thrive in a calm, structured environment. He'll do best with someone who understands working with high-energy dogs and is committed to positive reinforcement training. A home with a yard to stretch his legs-or a person who enjoys long walks and enrichment games-would be ideal.

**Good with kids?**
No. While he lived with young children in his previous home, due to his resource guarding, anxiety, and impulsive behavior, we recommend a home without children under 13.

**Good with other pets?**
Prince Charming lived peacefully with a cat and was described as friendly and playful with familiar dogs. At the shelter, he's shown some nervousness and overexcitement around unfamiliar dogs. If joining a home with another dog, structured introductions and slow acclimation are a must.

**Leash manners:**
This boy has a lot of energy on leash! He pulls and may lunge at small animals, but he's been making progress with decompression walks and reward-based training like "up/down" games, polite exchanges, and focus work. A front-clip harness and patience will go a long way.

**Overall health:**
Prince Charming is neutered, microchipped, and up to date on vaccines. He had a bout of kennel cough and some GI issues early on but has since recovered. He's currently a healthy 59-pound pup with a great appetite.

**Behavior determination:**
**Level 3** - Prince Charming is a bright, active dog who struggles with anxiety, low impulse control, and resource guarding. He's responded well to positive reinforcement techniques in the shelter and is ready for a savvy adopter who can continue building on that foundation.

---

**Fun facts about me:**

* I love car rides and am crate trained for up to 8 hours
* My previous family said I'm outgoing and playful
* I enjoy toys, treats, and enrichment games-just be ready for a high jump or two!
* I know how to sit, use wee-wee pads, and settle when given the right support
* My adoption fee has been **sponsored**, thanks to generous supporters!

---

**Ready to bring some royal energy into your life?** Prince Charming is full of love and potential-he just needs a family who can match his spirit and support his journey. If you're ready to meet your energetic new best friend, come see Prince today!

pets.name: Princess
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

pets.name: Princeton
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Princeton is on the at-risk list due to behavior concerns in his previous home. Princeton has a documented bite history involving two incidents with his previous owner. Neither incident broke skin from the information provided look to be when Princeton was in a heigthen state of excitement. Princeton in care is social with staff, enjoys attention, and going out for walks. Princeton does display some arousal concerns which currently we can redirect him with treats. Medically, Princeton is apparently healthy. Princeton was surrendered by his previous owner due to behavioral concerns in the previous home. His previous owner described him as vocal, mellow, and a bit of a couch potato. Princeton enjoys relaxing near his people and spending time in shared spaces like the living room. He is affectionate on his own terms, preferring to approach new people and situations slowly. Princeton enjoys his daily walks (45 minutes, 1-2 times a day) with mild to moderate leash pulling, is crate trained for a few hours, and has a medium energy level overall. While he can be fearful of handling, restraint, and car rides, and has shown low impulse control and anxiety that led to two minor bite incidents (no broken skin). Princeton would be best set up to succeed in an adult-only home wihtout cats or other smaller animals through a New Hope rescue partner with the guidance of a positive reinforcement-based certified professional trainer.

pets.name: Puzzle
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!
