pets.name: Quinn
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Quinn is a calm, quiet, loving, affectionate, gentle sweetheart. She loves attention, whether she is getting scratched behind her ears, getting brushed or getting full body rubs. Sometimes she just likes to lean into your legs with her warm, solid presence. Quinn also has an irresistible little dance that she shows off before heading outside for a walk; it's part prance, part excitement, fully adorable! She's great about sleeping through the night, gently snoring away she snoozes. During the day, her schedule includes lots of naps, and she always enjoys a kong or an enrichment toy. Quinn loves meeting new people, and she seems like she will be fine around other dogs because she shows no reactivity whatsoever when she's outdoors on a leash. Quinn might actually think she's a cat, because she's so content to be tranquil and cozy inside. Come meet Quinn to see her incredible personality for yourself - her mismatched floppy ears, her instant loyalty, and her mild and mellow temperament. There is an adorable video of me on social media! Click here to experience the cuteness!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I am a sweet, social, older gal, looking for the perfect forever home!

A Volunteer Wrote: It's craziness that the enchanting Quinn (Beautiful! Housetrained! No dog reactivity!) hasn't been swept away by a family yet, but it's only allowed her fan club here to grow exponentially, along with their enthusiasm. "Sweet! Sweet sweet!" one volunteer writes about her because one "sweet" isn't enough, while another wants to make sure her gentleness and kindness are noted. For my part, I want to call attention to the heart-melting prance she does for treats, which should be its own category on Dancing with the Stars. Please, give this dog the home she so deserves!

There is an adorable video of me on social media! Click here to experience the cuteness! What my friends at ACC say about me: My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet! It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children. I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them. I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you. I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets. I am a sweet, social, older gal, looking for the perfect forever home! A Volunteer Wrote: It's craziness that the enchanting Quinn (Beautiful! Housetrained! No dog reactivity!)  hasn't been swept away by a family yet, but it's only allowed her fan club here to grow exponentially, along with their enthusiasm.  "Sweet! Sweet sweet!" one volunteer writes about her because one "sweet" isn't enough, while another wants to make sure her gentleness and kindness are noted. For my part, I want to call attention to the heart-melting prance she does for treats, which should be its own category on Dancing with the Stars. Please, give this dog the home she so deserves!

pets.name: Raspberry Girl
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

A Volunteer Wrote: Raspberry is just the cutest little girl filled with surprises that are ALL GOOD! For instance: Her absolute joy with life and people, despite being in a kennel. And while she's certainly aware of the dogs that pass her, she had zero reaction to one who snarled at her, and she was all wagging tail with a fence greeting. Volunteers praise her for being "super easy," "very sweet," and "super snuggly," but the best comment may be from a stranger who passed her and said, "I can see the love in her eyes."

pets.name: Raven Roth
pets.summaryHtml:
Raven Roth is a bright and determined pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's working on building trust and developing positive behaviors around resource guarding, particularly with toys. Through consistent positive reinforcement, enrichment, and confidence-building exercises, Raven is learning that giving up her favorite items can lead to even better outcomes. She's making steady progress in practicing calm, cooperative behavior and becoming more comfortable with sharing.

**Meet Raven Roth!**
Raven Roth was surrendered to ACC when her family moved. At just two years old, this stunning black beauty is both sensitive and playful. She's affectionate with people she trusts and shines once given time to warm up. Raven has lived with adults, a child, and another dog. Now she's seeking a patient, experienced adopter who can help her feel safe and supported.

**My ideal home:**
Raven would thrive in a quiet, adult-only home where she can build trust gradually. She needs someone who understands canine body language and can respect her space. A calm environment and routine will bring out her affectionate, playful side.

**Good with other pets?**
Raven lived with another dog and shows friendly, playful behavior once comfortable. She can be shy with new dogs but warms up and initiates play. She should not live with cats or small animals due to a history of chasing and snapping.

**Leash manners:**
She pulls strongly and may react to small animals or strangers, especially near home. A front-clip harness and positive reinforcement will help her focus and feel more relaxed.

**Behavior determination:**
Level 3 - High-energy, affectionate, and needing guidance to manage anxiety, fear, and impulse control.

* Crate trained, up to 6 hours
* Knows "sit," "stay," "come," "lay down"
* Loves bones, balls, toys, and yard time
* Nervous in cars but loves walks
* Shows affection-on her terms

**Are you Raven's calm, confident guide?**
If you're looking for a smart, sensitive dog with lots of love to give, Raven might be your perfect match.

My Boroughbreaker writes: Raven Roth was an absolute joy on our trip to the park and Borough break on Sunday. She is truly the kind of dog who turns an outing into something special. She was calm, gentle, and perfectly well-behaved the entire time, showing no reactivity toward other dogs or people. In fact, she drew lots of attention from so many people who wanted to stop and meet her! Raven handled every interaction beautifully, wagging her tail and soaking up the love, especially when people approached her slowly and respectfully. She enjoys car rides, sitting contently and watching the world go by, and once she hit the park, she couldn't resist doing her happy zoomies in the sand! it was pure joy to watch!
Whoever adopts her will not only gain a best friend, but also a loving companion who will make every day brighter. ❤️🐾

pets.name: Renaissance
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

pets.name: Riley
pets.summaryHtml:
Due to the detailed behavior issues, this animal is only available for foster/adoption through one of ACC's New Hope Partners. If you are interested in adopting or fostering, please fill out the pre-screener form. This animal is not directly available for adoption through ACC and is only available by completing the pre-screener form.Adoption inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Riley has displayed concerns levels of fearfulness in care and has not warmed up to handling. He is avoidant of handlers and will hide under objects and frantically move away when approached. He has not allowed handling during his assessment and has displayed resource guarding behavior in kennel. We recommend placement with a New Hope partner who can provide any necessary behavior modification (force-free, positive reinforcement-based) and re-evaluate behavior in a stable home environment before placement into a permanent home.

pets.name: Ronnie
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Ronnie may be the world's best cuddle buddy. All she needs to be happy is laying next to her person, getting some belly rubs or ear scratches. She enjoys going on long walks but also happy laying around. She's crate trained and will sleep late in the morning, but will do a little tippy-tap dance when she first sees you waking up. She's crate trained and almost completely housetrained. Her face is a little lopsided, which only adds to her appeal as she stares at you with a little wink and head tilt. Ronnie will make the perfect addition to a home, filling it with unending love. Good with other pets?
Ronnie has lived with other pets in her previous home. At the shelter, she politely greeted another dog through a gate and then kept to herself. We always suggest slow introductions with resident pets, and we offer a 2-week trial adoption to help you see if Ronnie is a good fit with your family. Since ACC doesn't test with cats, we're not sure how she'd do with new feline friends, but we can help you with tips and advice!

Good with kids?
Due to the behavior seen in the care center, we feel that Ronnie may be intimidated by young children. She needs a slow approach and time to warm up. She should never be forced to interact with new people, and should be allowed to greet and initiate an interaction at her own pace. Older, gentle children should have an in-depth interaction prior to adoption.

How is my health?
Ronnie has some health concerns that our staff will discuss with you.

How are my leash manners?
Ronnie pulls moderately on the leash and is nonreactive to humans and dogs on walks.

What is my behavior assessment?
Ronnie has been assessed as a Level 2 dog. She would love to meet an adopter that will allow her to decompress at her own pace. With patience and understanding, Ronnie would make a very special companion!

pets.name: Runner
pets.summaryHtml:
Runner is a smart and energetic pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's working on managing on-leash reactivity and developing more focused, relaxed walking skills. Through positive reinforcement, structured leash work, and confidence-building exercises, Runner is learning how to stay calm and connected with his handler, even when distractions are nearby. She's making steady progress and showing great potential with each training session.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

A volunteer writes: Runner! A petite ball of fun and joy. This gray little lady is obviously adorable. She's bright and spunky, silly and social. And somehow has been with us almost two months already! She was found by the police wandering around alone in Queens. On walks, she is described as "bouncing" down the block, full of pep in her step. She has been a quick learner, learning a few pattern games with our behavior team. During her dog to dog greet, Runner barked at the other dog then ran back to her human friends. When we first met Runner, her skin was sensitive and her fur missing in lots of places. She is looking and feeling much better in the days since, her body and coat filling out. Runner is a big toy girl, and ready for a home to take joy in her puppy like personality.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

A volunteer writes: Runner! A petite ball of fun and joy. This gray little lady is obviously adorable. She's bright and spunky, silly and social. And somehow has been with us almost two months already! She was found by the police wandering around alone in Queens. On walks, she is described as "bouncing" down the block, full of pep in her step. She has been a quick learner, learning a few pattern games with our behavior team. During her dog to dog greet, Runner barked at the other dog then ran back to her human friends. When we first met Runner, her skin was sensitive and her fur missing in lots of places. She is looking and feeling much better in the days since, her body and coat filling out. Runner is a big toy girl, and ready for a home to take joy in her puppy like personality.
pets.description: Runner is a smart and energetic pup enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where she's working on managing on-leash reactivity and developing more focused, relaxed walking skills. Through positive reinforcement, structured leash work, and confidence-building exercises, Runner is learning how to stay calm and connected with his handler, even when distractions are nearby. She's making steady progress and showing great potential with each training session. What my friends at ACC say about me: My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet! It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children. I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them. pets.name: Ryder
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

A Volunteer Wrote: This girl has it all: so funny, so friendly, and so smart! She walks beautifully to the back where she play bows to dogs on either side until she realizes I'm the only one who is going to play with her-lucky me! Ryder is not only a great fetcher knows sit, down, paw, and spin, and she has mastered the art of snuggling. We are in love and you will be, too!

pets.name: Sam
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Sam arrived at the care center as an owner surrender. In the care center he becomes tense during handling attempts and often avoids engagement when he is uncomfortable or unsure. Sam shows clear signs of discomfort during interactions that feel intrusive and tends to shut down when stressed. He is also an affectionate and playful dog who enjoys going on walks and spending time with his family. He is an affectionate, playful, and loving dog who spends most of his time following his family around the home, playing with balls or plushies, and playing fetch. As a result, we recommend he is placed with one of our New Hope Partners.

pets.name: Sandy
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Sandy is a great girl: very smart, quiet, and doesn't bark at all. She'll approach you when she wants to play. Sandy loves to bring you ropes and toys, always eager for a spirited game of tug-of-war. She's an exceptional companion: intelligent, gentle, and remarkably quiet-she never barks. When she's in the mood to play, she'll come right over and let you know. To me, she is the perfect dog-adorable in every way and a joy to have around.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

pets.name: Santi
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would prefer someone who can be home with me most of the time.

pets.name: Sasha
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Sasha is an absolutely delightful and charming girl! She's full of energy and always ready to make friends. This little sweetheart, adores belly rubs, gentle petting, and being combed. She loves showing her affection through sweet licks and kisses. When it comes to meal time, she's a perfect little lady. Like vegetable too but only when they're chopped up. She is really smart too- she knows how to follow cue like sit, paw, stay, and come. To keep her happy and healthy, she needs daily exercise, fun activities, and mental challenges. With a little practice and patience, she'll get the hang of leash training. And let me tell you, when she's on the move, her wiggly dance will steal your heart-it's like she's doing the worm!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

A volunteer writes: Her hobby is flopping for belly rubs, which is convenient because ours is giving belly rubs! Sasha is, in a word, dreamy. I think she spent 90% of her time with us upside down, and the 10% she was right side up she was simply planning a flop so dramatically cute that we'd race over to rub her belly. Whether melting like a noodle against our legs while we pet her or literally just walking up to us and flopping unsolicited, it was all so perfect. It's hard to put a dog so affectionate back in a kennel, and we are comforted knowing other volunteers have taken a few minutes to give Sasha a belly rub. But this beautiful young girl should be the center of someone's universe, receiving all the love and affection her heart desires. If you can give that to her, please visit Sasha at Queens ACC

pets.name: Seven
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Seven is at risk due to behavioral reasons. Seven's previous owner states that he will lunge towards cats and small dogs. During his stay in the care center Seven has continued to be reactive. Noted to be highly kennel reactive and then will turn and snap at the handlers hands. After being returned to kennel Seven again snaps at the handlers hands. Medically Seven is apparently healthy.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I need a home without cats or small animals.

pets.name: Shanghai
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Shanghai!
Brought to MACC by NYPD Shanghai arrived nervous but trying her best. Since then she's shown us she's thoughtful, food-motivated, and capable of sweet check-ins with people she trusts. She can be hyper-alert in new places, but with patient handling she'll approach, sit for snacks, and follow along beside you. This shy-brave girl is ready for a calm, consistent home that lets her exhale and blossom.

My Ideal Home
A quiet, adult household with rescue-savvy humans who move slowly, use treats to build trust, and can offer a predictable routine. Decompression time, a cozy "safe spot," and positive-reinforcement training will help Shanghai feel secure. City noises can worry her, so quieter walking routes (or off-peak hours) are a plus.

Good with Kids?
No. Shanghai has displayed fearful behaviors and startle responses; she'll do best in an adult-only home where interactions can be managed thoughtfully.

Good with Other Pets?
Mixed signals in shelter. Through a fence she's offered play bows and mini zoomies, but in tight spaces and on leash she may bark/pull and can be hard to redirect. If considering dog-dog matches, plan on very slow, structured introductions after a full decompression period. For now, she may thrive as the only pet while she builds confidence.

Leash Manners
Walks with mild pulling; hypervigilant outside and can thrash or pull when startled by loud trucks or kennel room activity. Checks in for treats and will sit when asked. A front-clip harness, quiet routes, and "look at me" games will set her up for success.

Overall Health
Recovering well from a minor dart wound at intake. Recently treated for kennel cough with supportive care and antibiotics; eating better with time and TLC. Otherwise stable in shelter.

Behavior Determination
Experienced Adopters (Level 4) - Adult-only. Shanghai is a sensitive, fearful dog who may escalate when overwhelmed. Go slow, pair all new things with high-value rewards, and let her choose the pace of interaction. Decompression and fear-free handling are essential.

Other Fun Facts
• Takes treats gently and will offer a polite sit when she's feeling safe
• Brindle beauty with curious eyes who watches the world carefully
• Once she warms up, you'll see soft tail wags and those tentative little "is it OK?" check-ins that melt your heart

pets.name: Sheba Love
pets.summaryHtml:
My #Borough Breaker writes: We took a stroll to Starbucks first, and Sheba enjoyed a pup cup! She was a big fan. Then we hung out in the park for a while to have some water and treats, and relax in the shade since it was pretty hot out. We didn't end up staying long because she got very stressed when a dog walked by, even pretty far away from us. After that, we walked around some more and stopped for lunch at a restaurant with outdoor seating. Sheba loved the attention she got from the restaurant staff! When we finished lunch Sheba seemed pretty tired and ready to chill for a little bit, so we looked for somewhere to sit and relax where there weren't any dogs around so she could feel comfortable. We ended up spending about an hour just sitting on a bench and having some quiet time and treats! That was our last stop before bringing her back to the ACC. My boroughbreaker writes: We went to grab lunch at a nearby café, where Sheba Love was patient in sitting by my side. She has a big appetite and willingly took any treat from my hand gently. When I had bacon on the table, she waited for her turn. She did not climb or bark, instead she just stared at me with the most loving eyes. She was calm but alert, and made the perfect companion for a quiet lunch. She isn't spooked by loud sounds - it seems like she's used to the city noises. Sheba Love didn't pull once on the leash. She was always walking in sync by my side, easily redirected if I was going the wrong way. 

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

A volunteer writes: Sheba Love ❤️ We met Sheba just a few weeks ago. Her world was turned upside down when her humans lost their home, meaning she lost hers too. A quintessential baked pitato, she basked in all the sunny spots, favoring a little nook where we sometimes sit with our dogs. She panted gently in the sun and i remembered practically crying over how cute she looked. Sheba's previous guardians had such sweet things to say about her. They said their favorite things about her are, "She loves to cuddle, she is playful, she follows me wherever I'm at in closed off areas." They also told us she likes Ritz crackers and chicken and walks on the beach. Sheba doesn't enjoy dogs and will need a home where she can be an only. She's a perfectly aged 7 years old and needs your help.

pets.name: Silver
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have potential behavior challenges that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I am finding the shelter a bit overwhelming.

I am looking for a home with a patient person.

I can be slow to adjust to new environments. I prefer to take things at my own pace.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

A volunteer writes: Silver 🩶 the last time I saw Silver he was in his kennel, napping in the sun as it paused over his bed for a bit. He did a big, satisfying stretch and repositioned his big 70lb body. I blinked and imagined this same scene unfolding in a home. But today Silver is in that same kennel, after being found in a park 45 days ago. Reported friendly by the police who brought him in, he's been understandably scared during his time here. In spite of that he's also leaned in to petting during his assessment and greeted in a social manner. Now Silver is looking for a home to stretch his big body in. He's estimated to be 5 and the shelter is looking for a home with some experience to care for him. You can meet Silver at Queens ACC

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

pets.name: Sky Dragon
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: 
Sky Dragon is a most excellent house guest and a pleasure to live with! He is completely respectful of belongings and sleeps politely on his bed or rugs unless you explicitly invite him to the couch. He does not bark or pay any attention to neighbors in the hallway, and is often still asleep when you come home! Sometimes he even sleeps by the door waiting for you to come back and play! He loves long walks where he can smell all the news of the neighborhood. His other cute quirks include being a verryyyy deep sleeper with vivid dreams leading to twitching and the occasional talking! He enjoys watching other dogs on his walks and wants to make friends. He accepts baths but not blowdryers! He loves to cuddle and will paw you or give a cute seal sound if you stop petting him. He loves food puzzles and chewing his bully sticks too. Wherever you are in the house, he will come lay near you and keep you company.

My Borough breaker writes: I had the pleasure of taking Sky Dragon on a day trip. He was an absolute joy. We explored the beautiful landscapes of Central Park, from the Harlem Meer to the Conservatory Gardens. He was fascinated by the fountains, so much so that he got excited and tried to jump right in!
One of Sky Dragon's best qualities is his lovely, calm demeanor around distractions. He wasn't super reactive to the birds, squirrels, or even small dogs we passed, which made for a very pleasant and manageable walk.
Sky Dragon is a very treat-motivated boy. As I saw noted in his profile, he can get a little overzealous and nip when taking treats, but it's clear he means no harm. He does follow commands, but seems a little less likely to follow them if there is not a treat involved! So treats are a must!
I think he may have been a bit cautious about me at first, but after a few hours, he really started to come out of his shell and even trusted me enough to let me clean his face a bit.
He's an excellent communicator when it comes to his needs. During our walk, he let me know he wanted to take a break, so I took him inside thinking he was done. It turned out he just wanted a brief pause! He quickly asked to go back out, showing me that he simply prefers to take his adventures at his own pace with frequent, short breaks. He also has bursts of energy, like a little dragon taking flight, and I think he would make a fantastic jogging partner for an active person.
Sky Dragon was also the perfect brunch companion, sitting politely at my feet and enjoying the ambiance. He also knows he needs to stay hydrated! I was glad I had a backup water bottle, as he drinks frequently on his adventures, he went through 2 bottles on our first hour walk.

pets.name: Skye
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

pets.name: Snowboard
pets.summaryHtml:
My Boroughbreaker writes: Snowboard is an interesting girl. From her smooth coat down to her ice cold eyes, she is definitely a looker. She most definitely turns alot of heads when she's on a walk. In the beginning, she's a bit pulley on the leash, very energetic but that's because she is excited to just even be out. Took her to a nearby pet store & she grabbed a squeaky toy & ofcourse picked out her own treats. We came to a playground that just so happened to be empty & fenced with 1 entrance/exit & I let her roam freely! Huskies are known to want freedom to just run around & let off so much energy & Snowboard did just that! She was as free as the wind. She's very polite when taking a treat just as much as she is motivated to get one when asking her to do basic commands. On the way back, we encountered some pups & she was reactive, but if you continue to walk with her she will follow. Nonreactive to people walking by unless they want to pet her, she becomes the sweetest! Also, her leash manners become soft & she doesn't pull at all. If you're looking to win her over, give her some scratches near the tail & belly rubs, she will melt to the floor & you'll see just how vulnerable she is!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I need a home without cats or small animals.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I can go home today!

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

pets.name: Spike
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Spike is at risk due to behavioral concerns. Spike came to our Care center as a stray. He has been observed to be highly anxious, vocalizing persistently and pacing. During his stay with us Spike vocalizes loudly when seeing another dog, he fixates with a tense body and forward posture. He is not easily redirected. Spike continuously pulls hard when walking in the care center and on the street. He leash bites when handlers attempt to leash and grabbed handler's hand and releases quickly, no broken skin. It has been reported he has kennel reactivity when exiting/ entering his kennel. Spike enjoys enrichment and tolerates handlers scratching him. Medically, Spike is apparently healthy.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

pets.name: Stella
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: The first thing you need to know is that Stella snores. This is relevant because she will be on or near you whenever she or both of you are asleep. She is a snuggler and shameless lap dog (ahem, please note her size). She loves to play with her foster mom, spend time in the park, and tear into her toys (those magnificent ones with the squeaking ball inside!). She is working on her leash manners and is a sweet student. Her potty habits are excellent. She sports a rain coat when skies are gray and a lovely scarf when the sun shines...puppy pearls are in her future. If you need a true friend and love bug in your life, she is a lovely sidekick for any and every adventure!

🌟 Meet Stella!
Owner Surrender - Found as a Stray, Cared for by a Good Samaritan

Stella is a 4-year-old sweetheart with a calm presence and an affectionate soul. After being found wandering near a playground, she was taken in by a kind neighbor who hoped to find her family-but when no one came forward and medical care became too expensive, Stella was lovingly surrendered to ACC for a second chance. Now this mellow, loving pup is looking for her forever home.

🏡 My Ideal Home
Stella would be a wonderful match for someone seeking a relaxed, loyal companion. She's easy to walk, tolerant of new experiences, and happiest when lounging by your side or getting gentle pets. A home where she can continue healing and be treated like the cherished family member she is would be ideal.

👶 Good with Kids?
Yes! Stella previously lived with children and was described as tolerant and friendly. Her easygoing nature makes her a great match for families with respectful kids.

🐕 Good with Other Dogs?
Stella has not lived with other dogs, but she's been neutral and polite during greetings at the shelter. She could be a good fit with a calm, compatible canine companion after a slow introduction.

🦮 Leash Manners
Stella walks well on leash, occasionally pulling toward interesting smells but never unruly. She's a breeze to take on strolls and checks in sweetly with her handler along the way.

🧠 Behavior Determination: Level 1
Stella is a gentle, social, easygoing dog who seeks out human affection and calmly navigates new environments. She's tolerant, housetrained, and unbothered by handling-even when startled or restrained.

🎉 One Fun Fact
She loves Milk-Bone MaroSnacks and baby talk-and she'll gently lean into you for more when the treats are gone!

💸 Adoption Fee: Sponsored!
Thanks to ACC staff member Erica, Stella's adoption fee has been fully covered-all she needs now is your heart and home.

pets.name: Sterling
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

pets.name: Stormi
pets.summaryHtml:
🌩️ Meet Stormi! 🌩️

If you're looking for a loyal best friend who's equal parts playful companion and snuggly couch buddy, Stormi is your girl! This affectionate sweetheart loves nothing more than being near her people-whether that's joining in on your daily adventures or curling up beside you for some well-earned relaxation.

Stormi is a social, loving dog who enjoys being part of the action. You'll usually find her hanging out in the living room or wherever the family is gathered, happily soaking up all the attention she can get.

She's a dream when it comes to grooming-baths, brushing, even nail trims are no problem for this easygoing girl. Stormi walks beautifully on leash with very little pulling, and she's already mastered all her basic cues. She also loves car rides and is always ready to hop in for a fun outing!

Stormi's perfect home will be one where she can be the center of attention-she needs to be the only dog in the household. In return, she'll fill your life with love, laughter, and endless cuddles. 💕

My boroughbreaker writes: Stormi jumped right in my car with her tail wagging so happily. We went back to my house. I took her for a walk in the neighborhood. She enjoyed smelling and looking all around. She has very good leash manners and was a pleasure to walk with her. When we got in the house she was so excited to explore her new surroundings. She was very happy to meet members of my family. She's such a sweetheart. She enjoyed being scratched and hugged , she loved when I massaged her neck and head. She wanted to be close to me & snuggle up on the couch. Shes a sweetie of a dog.

My boroughbreaker writes: Stormi was an overall great dog, it was so sad to have to bring her back. Stormi is an absolute delight! I took her out on a borough break today, and while she started off excited in the new environment-pulling a bit and not too interested in treats-she quickly showed her true colors once she felt safe and settled. This beautiful, strong little chunky monkey absolutely shines in a calm, low-traffic area.
Once she relaxed, she took treats gently, walked like a dream, and covered me in the sweetest kisses. She was so grateful just to be outside and enjoy the world with someone by her side.
Stormi would thrive with someone who enjoys walking or running in quieter spaces. She's a fun, loving girl and I 100% recommend taking her out for a break-or even better, bringing her home as a foster. She's a chunky couch potato who just wants to be loved!

pets.name: Summit
pets.summaryHtml:
Here is a tightened version under 3,000 characters, fully within your required HTML template and style: --- Meet Summit!
Summit was found tied to a fence in a Bronx dog park, so we don't know his past - but here at ACC he's shown us he's a goofy, enthusiastic dog who loves carrying toys or blankets, soaking up belly rubs, and leaning in for affection. He's strong, curious, and happiest when he's exploring or playing with his people.

My Ideal Home
Summit is looking for an adult-only home with adopters comfortable with a large, powerful dog. He'll thrive with structure, enrichment, and positive-reinforcement training. A family who enjoys active outings and can give him regular exercise and clear routines will help him feel secure and at his best.

Good with Kids?
No. Summit can be jumpy and easily aroused when excited, so he's looking for an adult-only home where everyone can feel comfortable as he settles in and continues training.

Good with Other Pets?
Summit can get very focused on other dogs and may bark, pull, or become tense, especially on leash or at close range. He also loves chasing pigeons and small animals. For now, he may do best as the only pet while his new family continues working on his on-leash manners. If you have a resident dog, a slow, structured introduction is required.

Leash Manners
Summit is a strong walker who pulls with enthusiasm, especially when he spots birds, dogs, or moving objects like bikes. He can lunge or vocalize when overstimulated and sometimes needs treats or space to refocus. A front-clip harness, consistent training, and giving him room to decompress will set him up for success.

Overall Health
Healthy overall. He had a brief episode of soft stool that resolved with treatment and is feeling good now.

Behavior Determination
Level 3 - Experienced Adopters, Adult-Only Home. Summit was fearful at intake and can still become overstimulated, but he's affectionate, playful, and responsive when engaged thoughtfully. He'll benefit from a patient, experienced adopter who can help him continue learning how to slow down and feel safe.

Other Fun Facts
Summit's joy is contagious. Volunteers call him a "nice, goofy guy" and a "snuggle bunny." He loves playing two-toy fetch, trotting around with a blanket in his mouth, and leaning in for pets. His tail seems to have only one speed - full wag - and he'll make a devoted, fun companion for the right match.

pets.name: Sumo
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I have lived with dogs in my previous home.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

My Straycation Buddy Writes: Sumo brought so much joy to our home during the 3 days he was with us. He might be 8 years old, but has lovely energy; a "play hard - nap hard" kind of guy. He excels at fetch, outdoors and indoors, and never fails to cause a smile when he brings you a stuffed toy, or walks up and bumps you with his snout for a pet - especially during a boring conference call! He *loves* to cuddle & be close to his people, and got lots of passersby smiles when he lay down on a bench next to me, with his head in my lap. We also had the best nap together during my sick day! He's velvety soft to touch; instant relaxation. During the initial hours, he was quite pully apparently due to the novelty of the situation and stress, but by the next day walked on a loose leash or only mildly pulling. After initial adjustment, he is easy to walk. It helps that he's non-reactive: joggers, dogs, giant NYC rats don't faze him. (He is fully housetrained, too!) My favorite memory is relaxing together on a quiet stretch of the waterfront, with Sumo air scenting and watching the waves. His apple cronchies give me ASMR. Sumo also enjoys Greek yogurt, peanut butter, scrambled eggs, and... beets! He doesn't love new foods right away, but will give a few sniffs and tries, and sometimes it's a yes. He also likes to play "carwash", when he wiggles between your legs while you rub his sides! My boroughbreaker writes: I had such a fun day taking Sumo out on a borough break! He is such an all-around good boy with so much sweetness and energy. On our first walk, he pulled on the leash pretty strongly due to his excitement, but he never flinched walking by people or other dogs. He received so many smiles from people passing by, and his cutie ears (one up, one down) are absolutely adorable. He's a very energetic boy and had lots of zoomies when he first came into our apartment, but with enough time and patience, I think he'll quickly become more at ease in a new space, he just needs a little time to adjust! By our second walk, you could already tell he felt more comfortable: he walked slower, pulled less, and kept looking back at me to make sure I was enjoying the walk too! He's great with general commands like "sit," "down," "stay," "wait," and "leave it." He takes treats gently from your hand and loves rolling over to show off his big belly. He enjoys sitting in the sun and will hop right into your lap looking for cuddles or rest his head in your lap. I think he would do well in a calm, larger home where he has plenty of space to explore and play. He's incredibly sweet-natured and has so much love to give!

My favorite memory is relaxing together on a quiet stretch of the waterfront, with Sumo air scenting and watching the waves. His apple cronchies give me ASMR. Sumo also enjoys Greek yogurt, peanut butter, scrambled eggs, and... beets! He doesn't love new foods right away, but will give a few sniffs and tries, and sometimes it's a yes. He also likes to play "carwash", when he wiggles between your legs while you rub his sides!

My boroughbreaker writes: I had such a fun day taking Sumo out on a borough break! He is such an all-around good boy with so much sweetness and energy. On our first walk, he pulled on the leash pretty strongly due to his excitement, but he never flinched walking by people or other dogs. He received so many smiles from people passing by, and his cutie ears (one up, one down) are absolutely adorable.
He's a very energetic boy and had lots of zoomies when he first came into our apartment, but with enough time and patience, I think he'll quickly become more at ease in a new space, he just needs a little time to adjust! By our second walk, you could already tell he felt more comfortable: he walked slower, pulled less, and kept looking back at me to make sure I was enjoying the walk too!
He's great with general commands like "sit," "down," "stay," "wait," and "leave it." He takes treats gently from your hand and loves rolling over to show off his big belly. He enjoys sitting in the sun and will hop right into your lap looking for cuddles or rest his head in your lap.
I think he would do well in a calm, larger home where he has plenty of space to explore and play. He's incredibly sweet-natured and has so much love to give!

pets.name: Sundae
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Sundae is a gentle giant with a heart as big as his 75lb frame. This handsome 6-year-old is a master of transformation, moving from a frightened soul to a loving companion ready to melt your heart. Found abandoned, Sundae now finds joy in playtime and lazy afternoons lounging on the couch.
He's as well-mannered as they come, with perfect house-training skills and a polite demeanor on walks. While his curiosity might lead to a slight pull on the leash, Sundae always looks to his human for guidance and quickly adapts to new experiences with a bit of reassurance.
Sundae is searching for a forever home where he can feel safe, loved, and part of the family. Open your heart to Sundae, and be rewarded with endless love and loyalty. Are you ready to give Sundae the sweet life he deserves? Adopt him today!

pets.name: Sunny
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

pets.name: Taylor Sniff
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: Hi everyone, my name is Taylor Sniff, but you can call me Sniff for short. I love to play with toys, especially with my red Kong stuffed w/fresh apples and treats. I love to go for walks in the sunshine, hang out with my foster family, and explore the neighborhood. I am crate-trained, i know the command "sit" and am eager to learn more. I love to nap in my crate and on the rug, as long as it's near my foster family. Oh, I am house broken but have been working with my foster parents to let them know when i need to go out - I am only 10 months old so it's a work in progress. I don't bark at all but perhaps I should learn in order to communicate. I'm very friendly with my new human neighbors, adults and teens alike. My ideal home would be with a loving, patient family who are willing to teach me, play with me, give plenty snacks and loads of cuddles.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

pets.name: Terry
pets.summaryHtml:
Meet Terry - found as a stray, brought to ACC by NYPD after being discovered tied to a fence

A dignified senior (about 9 years old) with a marshmallow heart, Terry is the kind of dog who'll rest his head on your lap, lean in for ear and booty scratches, and take treats oh-so-gently. On walks he's an easygoing guy-mostly loose on leash, with the occasional "let's head back to the shelter" pause that a little coaxing fixes. He's been a quiet, thoughtful presence here, and he's more comfortable every day.

My ideal home
A calm, adult-only home that will let me decompress at my pace. I warm up with kindness and routine. I'd love daily strolls, comfy beds, and puzzle toys/chews to keep my senior brain happy. Slow introductions to new people and places, please.

My straycation buddy writes: Terry has been described as a sweet, older gentleman and that is spot on. He has wonderful manners - he doesn't beg for food when you're eating; he's good when he stays home alone; he's good on a walk - although he does have an opinion about where to go! He loves to explore the neighborhood with his nose, but if you have to get somewhere, he trots happily along. He's very low energy, and is happy to snooze the afternoon away. Terry likes a calm, quiet environment - lots of noise and people can make him shake with anxiety. I think he'd be good in a home with another dog, as he tried to approach other dogs in the park with a wagging tail while whining in anticipation of a good play date!

Behavior Level: 3
Tends to be fearful at first (tense body language, "whale eye," lip licking) and benefits from a quiet start and decompression period. Please let Terry choose the pace-no forced petting or fast introductions. Once he trusts you, he's affectionate and engaged.
Fun facts
Classic lap-leaner: will gently rest his head in your lap for pets
Scritch connoisseur-especially behind the ears and on the rump
Toy sampler who'll pick one up, lounge with it, then come back for snuggles
Gentle treat-taker and will sit nicely for snacks
If you're looking for a tender, golden-years companion who will meet you in the quiet moments and reward patience with deep loyalty, Terry's your guy. Bring your softest voice, your coziest blankets, and your kindest heart-he'll do the rest.
A Volunteer Wrote: If anyone in your life has missed the memo that dogs are the best thing in the world, introduce them to Terry, one of the best of the best! He's just an angel on four legs, walking perfectly, appearing housetrained, and so incredibly affectionate and dear in such a polite way. No wonder volunteers write "gentle and sweet," when they are describing them, and add, "A lovely walk!"

pets.name: Tinkerbell
pets.summaryHtml:
Tinkerbell arrived at MACC as a stray with no known history. During intake she was observed to hard bark, hard stare, and lunge towards handlers. Throughout her stay in the care center Tinkerbell has remained highly fearful. Noted to have a tense body, tucked tail and will baulk while on leash. This behavior is not able to be redirected easily. When unfamiliar handlers approach Timberbell will growl and hard bark at them. With familiar handlers Tinkerbell allows contact and displays a low tail wag. Due to the detailed behaviors we recommend an experienced adult only home.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

pets.name: Titan
pets.summaryHtml:
💫 Meet Titan! ✨

Meet Titan, a 6-year-old bundle of joy with a heart full of love and a personality that lights up the room! Friendly, outgoing, and always ready for fun, Titan is the kind of dog who makes everyone feel like his best friend.

He absolutely loves treats and attention, and his goofy, affectionate nature makes him a favorite with everyone who spends time with him. Whether he's out on a walk, seeking attention, or just hanging out by your side, Titan brings pure happiness wherever he goes.

When Titan first arrived at the shelter, he was very underweight - but thanks to great care and a strong spirit, he's bounced back and is now feeling strong, healthy, and ready for his forever home.

If you're looking for a dog who will make you smile every day and shower you with love, Titan is your guy. Come meet him and see just how special he'll make you feel.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: 
Dear Santa Paws
This year, I don't want toys or treats. All I want for Christmas is a family to call my own. I've been a very good dog, and I promise to be the best boy ever if you can help me find my forever home. I dream of a warm place to snuggle and a loving person to share my days with. Please send my person to find me so I can leave this shelter behind and start my new life with them. Thank you, Santa Paws 🐾 🐾🐾🐾
Love Titan

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Titan was so excited to see me. I took him on 3 BoroughBreaks already. He couldn't wait to jump in my car and go back to my house. He is very good in the car ride. He likes to ride in the passenger seat and look out the window.
Titan is such a sweet and gentle loving dog. He likes to lay right next to me on the couch and rest his head on me. He especially loves Costco rotisserie chicken. I make sure I always have it for him.
He is also playful, he loves to run around and interact with me.
He understands when I tell him no!
Titan will make a great addition to your home with his lovable sweet personality. You can't help not falling in love with him.

If you're looking for a dog who will make you smile every day and shower you with love, Titan is your guy. Come meet him and see just how special he'll make you feel.

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: 
Dear Santa Paws
This year, I don't want toys or treats. All I want for Christmas is a family to call my own. I've been a very good dog, and I promise to be the best boy ever if you can help me find my forever home. I dream of a warm place to snuggle and a loving person to share my days with. Please send my person to find me so I can leave this shelter behind and start my new life with them. Thank you, Santa Paws 🐾 🐾🐾🐾
Love Titan

My #BoroughBreak Buddy Writes: Titan was so excited to see me. I took him on 3 BoroughBreaks already. He couldn't wait to jump in my car and go back to my house. He is very good in the car ride. He likes to ride in the passenger seat and look out the window.
Titan is such a sweet and gentle loving dog. He likes to lay right next to me on the couch and rest his head on me. He especially loves Costco rotisserie chicken. I make sure I always have it for him.
He is also playful, he loves to run around and interact with me.
He understands when I tell him no!
Titan will make a great addition to your home with his lovable sweet personality. You can't help not falling in love with him.

pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I need a home without cats or small animals.

I need a home where there are no other dogs.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I prefer to call the shots and enjoy coming to you when I'm ready for pets.

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

pets.name: Toast
pets.summaryHtml:
My adoption fee has been sponsored thanks to a generous donor!

Toast is a handsome, friendly, and outgoing companion. He is described as a very chill dog who loves cuddling, playing tug-of-war, and toys. He's fully housetrained and loves car rides, making him a great partner for adventures. Toast thrives on human interaction, preferring to spend most of his time wherever people are. Toast's ideal home is one that can provide structured walks, consistent training, and plenty of cuddles. With patience and love, Toast is ready to be your most loyal and affectionate companion. Come meet this sweet boy today!

My foster writes: My name is Toast but I also go by Toasty, Toaster Stroodle Dandy, and Mr Wiggle Butt. I may look all tough but I'm really just a love bug, cuddle monster. I love being with my people and cuddling up on the couch. Some have called me a velcro dog because I will follow my foster mom all over the house. I'm also very food motivated so training is super easy. I'm excellent at 'sit' and i'm learning 'leave it' like a pro. I love puzzle games so bring your best!

My foster writes:
"Sweet, loyal and ready to bloom"! Meet Toast. This affectionate and devoted dog is quick to learn, eager to please, and everyday his confidence increases a little more. With patience, guidance and love, Toast will be your constant companion and BFF. He seems to have had a rough start in life, but it's clear that he wants to love and be loved. He is so ready for his forever home, and his happy ever after.

pets.name: Trooper
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

Not only do I pull at heart strings, but I also pull on leash! I will need someone to help me with my leash manners.

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

pets.name: Turk
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I am excitable and energetic! I will need positive outlets for my energy!

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

A Volunteer Wrote: I was enchanted by Turk, who is as smart as he is charming, as he  tried to seduce me to take him out from his pop up crate, all tail wags and play bows. Luckily a staff member obliged so I could watch him show off his tricks, including sit and paw and endless affection (plus no reactivity to other dogs!) Turk got a rap for counter surfing and taking his treats with too much enthusiasm when he first arrived, but he was all soft mouth on our outing, and after all, who doesn't love a food enthusiast? We sure do love Turk!

pets.name: Tyrone
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love to be loved, but on my own terms! Let's brush up on some canine body language together!

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I have medical needs that staff will address with you when you meet me.

pets.name: Tyson Michael
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

A Volunteer Wrote: Tyson Michael has shown himself to be a lovely, easy-going guy around dogs and people, and a fan of playing with toys. But as the days of his being here have grown longer, he has come to prefer the comfort of a walker's arms to showing off his side-by-side walking skills. Tyson Michael would so benefit from being out of a kennel and into a loving environment sooner rather than later, where he can begin to shine again!

pets.name: Vale
pets.summaryHtml:
❄️ Meet Vale! ❄️

Say hello to Vale, a stunning and spirited Husky with a heart as big as her personality! This sweet and vocal girl was found as a stray, and while her past is a bit of a mystery, her playful and loving nature has quickly won everyone over.

Vale is an active, energetic dog who loves to run, play, and explore the world around her. True to her Husky roots, she's happiest when she's got room to move-she enjoys spending time in the backyard or relaxing on her bed indoors once she's had her fill of fun. She can be a strong puller on leash, so she'll do best with someone who can keep up with her strength and enthusiasm!

Vale is crate trained and does very well in her crate for short periods. She also loves car rides, especially when she can look out the window and take in all the sights.

This clever girl knows a few commands-like sit and paw-and understands both English and Spanish! Her favorite things in life are running, playing with toys, and snacking on all kinds of treats (bananas are a favorite!).

Vale would thrive in an active home that can match her energy and give her plenty of exercise, structure, and love. If you're looking for a fun-loving, bilingual Husky who will fill your life with joy and excitement, Vale is ready to be your new best friend! 🐾💙

My boroughbreaker writes: Vale lived up to her breed by "chatting away" (howling like a husky 😂)! She voiced her opinion to open the car window so when I arrived home I opened the window wide enough for her little head to stick out (see pictures). She has a brown and blue eye...she's just precious! At first she was very skittish and guarded. Though once she felt comfortable and trusted me, she was more relaxed to be herself. She needs someone to trust and then she will be YOURS! She responds to "SIT" opposed to "sit down" and btw then expects a treat (so please cheat her out of that pleasure😍). Eventually she was quite relaxed and enjoyed a rope pull toy and playing around. She's a husky so be prepared for the "shed" 🙃. My time with her was limited though I didn't try to pet her. She definitely needs to be reassured you are a "safe" person.

pets.name: Velvet
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: In her notes, Velvet's veterinarian noted how polite she is, and SHE IS. In addition to being the sweetest and most loving pup, and she knows how to be patient with people who want to give her attention and with me when I'm preparing her food. The only thing she is not patient about it is when she sees there's a chance that we might be heading toward the park. Then the excited puppy energy takes over. Velvet loves tennis balls, soccer balls, squeaky toys (she is a very efficient squeaker-remover), fetch, and tug of war. Her tail is powerful and she wags it with gusto when she is happy. Velvet loves to run but she is also happy as a work-from-companion, having attended many zoom meetings with me and listened in on countless work phone calls. She lounges about during the day for a surprising number of hours. She cuddles me at night (yes, of course, she sleeps in my bed and gets her hair everywhere), and sometimes snores (it's adorable), and has little dreams where she is apparently paddling her paws in a wide ocean or something like that. Velvet is not a picky eater and takes her meds in half-vienna-sausages with no problems at all. I've only been in two ubers with her and no city buses, but she is making great strides with the subway where she is peaceful and patient and never tires of the public attention her brindle coat guarantees. She knows perhaps 20 commands and we're working on "privacy" (so a human can use the bathroom in peace) and "slow" when going down stairs. I love her a lot. She has quickly become my best friend. I am sure you will love her, too.

What my friends at ACC say about me:

I'm ready to learn! I need a patient person who has the time to work on training with me.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I love getting pets and - you guessed it - snuggles!

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.

I am playful and cute!

pets.name: Willow
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I'll need daily interaction with you as I get used to my new life.

I am playful and cute!

I will need appropriate toys and positive outlets for my energy.

It could be with you! Click here to learn more about the adoption process!

I can go home today!

A Volunteer Wrote: Willow would like to invite you to a wiggle party, although we'll tell you upfront that no matter how much you train, there is no chance you can out-wiggle this enthusiast! Willow is so happy to get any kind of attention she wags her entire body, especially when it involves a hug, a treat, and an attempted kiss. Willow's been a little shy on the street here--it can be a stressful time for the dogs, both being in the shelter and leaving it--but at the backyard she shows off her exuberant spirit, her excellent fetching skills, and her adorable joie de vivre. We're so eager to see her in a wonderful home--please consider letting it be yours!

pets.name: Winks
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

I would appreciate slow introductions to new people and places to help me feel safe.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

I don't always like to share my food, toys or bedding with other animals.

A volunteer writes: Winks is the cutest little warlock we've ever seen and we find out quickly how he got his name. Both eyes head in opposite directions giving him excellent peripheral vision, though we aren't sure if he'll ever be able to make direct eye contact with you. Maybe that's how he puts his spells on people, because it only takes a few minutes for us to be bewitched by him! He offers us his paw, rolls over for belly rubs (and a glorious belly he has!) and gets a bit vocal when we aren't giving him treats fast enough. And when it's time to go back inside, he lays down and frogs his legs out in protest. Whatever voodoo he is using is working, because we are totally smitten with Winks! Winks' guardian made the difficult decision to surrender when they became homeless. They tell us he's been friendly with strangers and kids, and hasn't spent much time with other cats or dogs. Winks is social, affectionate, active, playful and vocal and likes being bathed and hanging out where the people are. He doesn't like his paws touched, car rides make him nervous and he has shown some food guarding behaviors in his former home. In a gate greet, Winks was soft and wiggling when meeting a male dog and ignored a female dog. He is recommended to an experienced hom with kids over the age of 13. Winks is an energetic and highly motivated pup in our Shelter Scholars program, where he's learning to feel more at ease around food resources. Using gentle handling, structure, and positive associations, Winks is developing a more relaxed approach to mealtime. His willingness to learn is helping him make steady and rewarding progress. My Boroughbreaker writes: Drove right to a pet store to get some chew toys for our first stop. There were alot of FIRSTS' for Winks. His first boroughbreak. First car ride. First time someone called to ask for him specifically! After we picked up some chew toys, our second stop? straight to white castle & got him some chicken rings. It's like he instantly knew he was getting spoiled because the little cries & drools & tail wagging of excitement was unbearable. Third stop, HIGHLAND PARK. This is where he unleashed is inner puppy. You throw a toy & he'll make a run for it & chew it like no other. He's definitely a shelter scholar. He knows the commands such as "Sit", "Paw" & "Up!" (He'll jump up & hug you) with or without a treat! He definitely minds his business when people or dogs are calmly walking by. He also pulls on the leash when he gets interested in scents, but no worries, after he marks his territory, he carries along.

pets.name: Xena
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

Xena is at risk for behavior reasons. Xena was initially highly fearful entering the shelter but is warming up towards staff. Despite her being more social, she has begun leash biting exiting her kennel. Xena has a bite to the other resident dog and has shown barrier frustration when other dogs pass her kennel. She should be the only pet in an adult only home. Medically, she has some dental disease but is an otherwise healthy dog. 👑 Meet Xena 👑 Xena is highly fearful in the care center, currently allowing only minimal handling. The shelter environment is overwhelming for her, which means she will require a slow, structured decompression period and gradual introductions to new people once adopted. Her fearfulness in the shelter may not reflect who she will be in a stable, loving home, but it does mean she needs an adopter who is patient, gentle, and committed to moving at her pace. With consistency, time, and a quiet household, Xena has every potential to regain her confidence and show the affectionate, playful, and devoted dog she has always been. She will thrive with someone who understands her sensitivities and is ready to give her the supportive, understanding home she deserves. Her owner describes her as a loving, social, and affectionate dog who truly thrives in a calm home environment. She is very active and playful, enjoys being wherever her people are, and has a history of being gentle, clean, and closely bonded with her family. At home, she loved bath time and water, allowed brushing and nail trims, walked 1-2 times daily with mild to moderate pulling, and was comfortable spending time in her large crate. She also knows "Sit," enjoys car rides, and loves her hard bone and rope toys. It is important for future adopters to know that Xena must be the only pet in the home. She will do best without other animals, allowing her to feel secure and receive the focused support she needs.

pets.name: Yams
pets.summaryHtml:
This pet needs emergency placement. Please click here to go to our emergency placement page for more information.

This pet is available only through ACC New Hope partners. To adopt or foster, please complete the pre-screener form below. Inquiries sent directly to ACC will not receive a response.

Pre-Screener Form

Yams is at risk due to medical reasons. Yams has a lameness of his right forelimb, causing by a deformity of his paw. As a result, he has significant osteoarthritis and is reluctant to walk - impacting his quality of life and our ability to meet his behavior needs in the shelter. He is also mildly overweight and has mild dental disease. Yams would benefit from a consult with an orthopedic specialist and will need continued pain relief and medical management for his chronic lameness. A low stress and comfortable environment will support his behavioral health and mobility. Yams was brought to the care center as a stray and has spent time with his finder. The finder stated that Yams as friendly, outgoing, tolerant, and not picky with food.

pets.name: Zam
pets.summaryHtml:
Zam is an enthusiastic and intelligent dog enrolled in our Shelter Scholars program, where he's learning to stay grounded during walks by working on on-leash reactivity. With patience and practice, he's beginning to replace reactive behaviors with calm focus and improved leash manners, turning daily outings into opportunities for growth.

Meet Zam!
Owner surrender with prior ACC history; his family could no longer provide the time and housing he needs. In care, he's shown both a sweet, people-focused side and some stress in busy kennel areas.

My Ideal Home
Experienced, adult-only adopters who can offer structure, a calm routine, and positive-reinforcement training. Decompression time, enrichment (sniff walks, food puzzles, long-lasting chews), and clear guidance will help him feel safe and settle in.

Good with Kids?
Recommended no children under 13 due to fearfulness and sensitivity to handling.

Good with Other Pets?
Recommended single-pet home. In shelter play/near-dog settings he's shown tension, barking, and fixating; we also recommend no dog parks.

Leash Manners
Leashes easily and can walk with light to moderate tension, but may pull hard and vocalize when he sees other dogs. Use distance, "look at me/let's go" games, and a front-clip harness to support success. Redirect to treats or a sniff break before he escalates.

Overall Health
Veterinary exam lists him as apparently healthy; heartworm tests have been negative. He is neutered and up to date on core vaccines. A dental cleaning (COHAT) is recommended at adoption.

Behavior Determination & Other
Level 3. Recommendations: adult-only home; single pet; no dog parks. Potential challenges noted: fearful in new situations, on-leash reactivity/barrier frustration, occasional leash mouthing under stress. Training focus: slow, choice-based introductions, reward check-ins, and consistent management around other dogs.

Fun Facts
• Housetrained
• Knows sit, stay, shake/paw
• Food-motivated and enjoys snuffle mats/puzzles
• Loves car rides and playing with balls

• Loves car rides and playing with balls

pets.name: Zazu
pets.summaryHtml:
My Adoption Fee is Sponsored!

My foster writes: I've had a lot of foster pups and Zazu truly is something special. I don't think I've met a sweeter soul. Zazu is very easy going and knows all the basic commands. She is SO happy when it's time for a walk but equally loves being a couch potato while you binge watch. Zazu doesn't ask for much and is very low maintenance. She sleeps soundly through the night, is crate trained, housetrained, a professional cuddler and big lap dog. Zazu gets along well with our medium sized dog. She is a little weary of small dogs, especially when they yap at her. Zazu walks beautifully on a leash. She may pull for a second if she sees another dog but quickly gets back on track with her walker (especially if they have a treat)! Zazu is an easy going, well behaved pup that would be ideal for any family, even new dog owners! She is very gentle and doesn't jump, making her a wonderful family pup for kids. I truly can't believe she hasn't found her forever home yet. Bonus: She is estimated to be 7yrs but this spring chicken recently had a full glow up at the vet and came back with a clean bill of health! Meet Zazu - Your New Cuddle Companion! Zazu was brought to us by officers at the 116th precinct after she was found abandoned in Queens. Despite her rough start, Zazu has been nothing but gentle, wiggly, and ready for love. My ideal home: Zazu is a senior sweetheart looking for a calm, loving home where she can snooze in sunny spots, enjoy leisurely strolls, and be spoiled with affection. Good with Kids? Zazu is gentle, social, and tolerant of handling-traits that could make her a great match for a family with respectful kids. As always, a meet-and-greet is recommended. Good with other dogs? Zazu has shown mixed responses with other dogs in shelter playgroups and seems more comfortable avoiding confrontation. A solo-pet household or slow introductions at home would be best. Leash Manners: She walks politely with minimal pulling and happily follows her handler's lead. Just bring the leash and some treats-Zazu's ready to go!

pets.name: Zeke
pets.summaryHtml:
What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I will flourish in a calm environment and a low-traffic home.

I can be slow to adjust to new environments. I prefer to take things at my own pace.

I would do best in a home with only adult humans.

I'm sensitive and shy. I'll need extra help from you.

pets.name: Zoey
pets.summaryHtml:
My foster writes: She is the cutest, snuggliest dog! She will follow you around everywhere around your house and ask for pets. She super excited and ready for pets in the morning, and responds to your energy- she'll sit beside you calmly as you work, or play with you when you want to. She is the sweetest dog!

What my friends at ACC say about me:

My history is a mystery and my friends here do not know much about me yet!

It is unknown if I have ever lived with other animals or children.

I am playful and cute!

I will need daily physical activity to keep me healthy and happy!

I would do best in a home without very tiny humans, although I could be open to older human children once I meet them.
